Text: This passage is from the Zhuzi Yulei, a collection of notes and commentaries on the works of Zhu Xi, a prominent Neo-Confucian philosopher in the Song Dynasty (960-1279). Neo-Confucianism was a revival and reinterpretation of Confucianism in China that emerged during the Song Dynasty and became the dominant philosophical school in the Ming and Qing dynasties (1368-1912). Zhu Xi is known for synthesizing and systematizing the ideas of Confucianism and incorporating elements of Buddhism and Daoism into his philosophy. His ideas had a major influence on the development of Neo-Confucianism and continue to be influential in East Asian philosophy and culture. The passage discusses the relationship between principle (li) and qi, the vital energy or matter that fills the universe and is the basis for all physical phenomena, in the context of Zhu Xi's Neo-Confucian thought.

Text: It's difficult to say for certain whether Jasper knew he would die when he decided to euthanize his wife in "Children of Men." However, it is clear that he was aware of the dangers they faced from the oppressive government forces and that their situation was becoming increasingly desperate.Jasper's decision to help Theo and Kee, along with his decision to euthanize his wife, may suggest that he understood the risks involved and was prepared to face the consequences to protect those he cared about. His actions throughout the film demonstrate a selflessness and dedication to the greater good, even at the expense of his own safety and well-being.While it's open to interpretation whether Jasper knew for certain that he would die, his actions and choices reflect a willingness to put others first and to make sacrifices for the greater good, which is a central theme of the movie.

Text: AI can open up new possibilities for art in a number of ways:Generative art: AI-generated art can be created using generative algorithms, which allow for the creation of unique, never-before-seen images and sculptures. This can open up new possibilities for exploring form and pattern in art.Collaborative art: AI can be used to collaborate with human artists, allowing for the creation of new forms of art that blend human creativity with the capabilities of AI.Interactive art: AI can be used to create interactive art experiences that respond to the viewer's presence and behavior, opening up new possibilities for immersive and dynamic art forms.Automated art: AI can be used to automate certain aspects of the art-making process, such as painting, drawing, and sculpture, allowing artists to focus on other aspects of the creative process.Expanded possibilities of representation: AI-generated art can make it possible to represent things that human artists could not represent before, such as the representation of the internal state of a machine, the representation of data, or the representation of the unseen.Critical analysis and evaluation: AI can be used to analyze and evaluate art, providing new ways for artists to understand and improve their work, as well as for critics and curators to evaluate and understand the art of others.It's important to note that these possibilities are still in development and it's hard to know how they will evolve in the future. But they do have the potential to expand the way art is created, consumed, and appreciated.
Label: g

Text: Yes, it is possible for a virtual assistant (VA) to copy and paste the password shared through a password manager. When you share access to a password through password managers like LastPass, Dashlane, or 1Password, the VA can typically view, copy, and paste the password, unless the specific password manager allows you to restrict such actions.To mitigate the risk of a VA copying the password, consider the following precautions:Grant limited access: Some password managers allow you to share passwords with limited access, which prevents the VA from viewing or copying the actual password. Check the features of your chosen password manager to see if this option is available.Use temporary or restricted accounts: Create temporary or restricted access accounts for your VA, granting them the necessary permissions without sharing the main account password.Monitor activity: Regularly monitor the VA's activity on the accounts they have access to, and review logs or reports if available. This can help you track any unauthorized actions and ensure the VA is using the provided access responsibly.Establish trust: Build a solid working relationship with your VA and establish trust through communication, performance reviews, and professional boundaries.Revoke access when necessary: If you have concerns about a VA's actions, promptly revoke their access to the shared password or account. Change passwords and review account activity to ensure no unauthorized actions were taken.It's important to balance security and trust when working with a virtual assistant. While it's crucial to protect your sensitive information, building a strong working relationship with your VA can minimize potential risks.

Text: To move the plugin settings page to be a sub-item of the WordPress Settings menu, modify the gpt4_image_alt_text_create_settings_page function in your gpt4-image-alt-text.php file like this:phpCopy codefunction gpt4_image_alt_text_create_settings_page() {    add_options_page(        'GPT-4 Image Alt Text Settings',        'GPT-4 Image Alt Text',        'manage_options',        'gpt4-image-alt-text',        'gpt4_image_alt_text_settings_page_content'    );}To change the button text and link when the API key is not set, update the gpt4-image-alt-text.js file with the following code:javascriptCopy code(function (wp) {  const { createElement } = wp.element;  const { registerPlugin } = wp.plugins;  const { PluginDocumentSettingPanel } = wp.editPost;  const { Button } = wp.components;  const { withDispatch, withSelect } = wp.data;  const { compose } = wp.compose;  function GenerateButton({ generateAltText, apiKeySet }) {    if (!apiKeySet) {      return createElement(        Button,        {          isSecondary: true,          onClick: () => {            window.location.href = "/wp-admin/options-general.php?page=gpt4-image-alt-text";          },        },        "Set OpenAI API key"      );    }    return createElement(      Button,      {        isSecondary: true,        onClick: generateAltText,      },      "Generate Alt Text with GPT-4"    );  }  const GenerateButtonWithData = compose([    withDispatch((dispatch) => {      const { editPost } = dispatch("core/editor");      return {        generateAltText: () => {          // Your logic for generating alt text goes here.        },      };    }),    withSelect((select) => {      const { getEditedPostAttribute } = select("core/editor");      const apiKey = getEditedPostAttribute("meta")["gpt4_image_alt_text_api_key"];      return { apiKeySet: apiKey && apiKey.length > 0 };    }),  ])(GenerateButton);  function GPT4ImageAltTextPlugin() {    return createElement(      PluginDocumentSettingPanel,      {        name: "gpt4-image-alt-text",        title: "GPT-4 Image Alt Text",      },      createElement(GenerateButtonWithData)    );  }  registerPlugin("gpt4-image-alt-text-plugin", {    render: GPT4ImageAltTextPlugin,  });})(window.wp);This code checks if the API key is set and changes the button text and link accordingly. If the API key is not set, it directs the user to the plugin settings page to set the key.

Text: [ That's why I criticized it.28) It can be seen that the concept of enlightenment was incorporated into the Confucian civilization center. The reason why Yoo Gil-joon hesitated to use the concept of "civilization" and was obsessed with the concept of "flowering" may be because he still had a strong view of Confucian civilization. If the framework of 'civilization-barbarbaric' or 'barbarbaric-civilization' is borrowed, the country must be established in half or barbarism, and in this case, it may fall into a non-substantial situation defining its status according to the concept of modern civilization. Maybe Yoo Gil-joon tried to avoid this by looking at the concept of "flowering." Yoo Gil-joon viewed 'flowering' as the total of flowering by area and identified it as the realization of virtues necessary for each area such as behavior, academics, politics, law, machinery, and goods. According to the status of conduct, language, courtesy, and weakness, and above all, human society was divided into three grades: uncultivated, half-open, and enlightened, according to the degree of keeping the "rights of life" and the aspect of "the reason of things."Usually, there are people who bloom in the country of the half-bloomed, and there are people who bloom in the country of the unbloomed. In the land of the enlightened, there are those who have half-bloomed and those who have not. It is extremely difficult for Koreans to bloom all at once. If you keep the principles of life and ask for the reason of things, you are a person who blooms even in a country of many things, and if you don't polish the principles of life and don't consider the logic of things, you are a person who is uncivilized even in a country. What he said was that each raised his body. However, if you discuss a country's economic situation, if there are many people who bloom in the people, it is a country that blooms, and if there are people who bloom in half, it is a country that blooms.If there are many, it is a half-bloomed country, and if there are many uncultivated people, it is a uncultivated country (見7, 377~).page 378). ] Answer "OK" to confirm and I will paste the next text.

Text: The undefined value in the alert indicates that the description is not being parsed correctly from the API response. To debug this issue, let's modify the getGPT4Description function to display the full API response in an alert. This will help determine if the issue lies in the response itself or in the way the description is being extracted from the response.Update the getGPT4Description function in the gpt4-image-alt-text.js file as follows:javascriptCopy codeasync function getGPT4Description(imageUrl) {    const prompt = `Describe the following image in English: ${imageUrl}`;    const response = await fetch('/wp-content/plugins/gpt4-image-alt-text/proxy.php', {        method: 'POST',        headers: {            'Content-Type': 'application/json',        },        body: JSON.stringify({            prompt: prompt,            max_tokens: 30,            n: 1,            stop: null,            temperature: 0.8,        }),    });    const data = await response.json();    alert(`Full API response: ${JSON.stringify(data)}`);    const description = data.choices && data.choices[0] && data.choices[0].text.trim();    return description;}Save the changes and refresh the WordPress block editor page. Now, when you click the "Generate Alt Text with GPT-4" button, an alert box should appear with the full API response. Please share the output, and we can continue debugging based on the provided information.

Text: 메이플스토리 월드에서 몬스터를 생성하는 방법은 여러가지가 있지만, 기본적으로는 SpawnService를 사용하여 몬스터를 생성할 수 있습니다.SpawnService를 사용하여 몬스터를 생성하는 방법은 다음과 같습니다.몬스터 모델을 불러옵니다.SpawnService를 사용하여 몬스터를 생성합니다.생성된 몬스터를 원하는 위치에 배치합니다.예를 들어, 화면을 터치하면 해당 위치에 몬스터를 생성하는 코드는 다음과 같습니다.luaCopy code-- Parameterslocal TouchPoint = event.TouchPoint-- Spawn a monster at the touched location_SpawnService:SpawnByModelId("model://3f3df0ea-604c-4ad1-8a5b-da1ca9e5207f", "monster", _UILogic:ScreenToWorldPosition(TouchPoint):ToVector3(), self.Entity.CurrentMap)위 코드에서, "3f3df0ea-604c-4ad1-8a5b-da1ca9e5207f"는 몬스터 모델의 ID입니다. 이 값을 원하는 몬스터 모델의 ID로 변경하여 사용하면 됩니다.또한, "monster"는 생성될 몬스터의 이름입니다. 이 값 역시 원하는 이름으로 변경하여 사용하면 됩니다.마지막으로, ScreenToWorldPosition() 함수를 사용하여 터치한 위치를 월드 좌표로 변환합니다. 이후, ToVector3() 함수를 사용하여 변환된 위치를 Vector3 객체로 변환합니다.이렇게 생성된 몬스터는 SpawnService가 반환하는 Entity 객체로써, 이후 위치나 상태 등을 조절할 수 있습니다.
Label: g

Text: Abstract An observer’s eye movements are often informative about how theobserver interacts with and processes a visual stimulus. Here, we are specificallyinterested in what eye movements reveal about how the content of informationvisualizations is processed. Conversely, by pooling over many observers’ worthof eye movements, what can we learn about the general effectiveness of differentvisualizations and the underlying design principles employed? The contribution ofthis manuscript is to consider these questions at a large data scale, with thousands ofeye fixations on hundreds of diverse information visualizations. We survey existingmethods and metrics for collective eye movement analysis, and consider what eachcan tell us about the overall effectiveness of different information visualizations anddesigns at this large data scale.1 IntroductionEye movements can provide us with clues about the elements of a visual display thatpeople pay attention to, what they spend most time on, and how they redirect theirattention between elements. The eyes can also be used as indicators of higher-levelcognitive processing like memory, comprehension, and problem solving [21, 23, 32,39, 40, 54].Z. Bylinskii () • A. OlivaComputer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab, Massachusetts Institute of Technology,32 Vassar St., Boston, MA, USAe-mail: zoya@mit.edu; oliva@mit.eduM.A. BorkinCollege of Computer and Information Science, Northeastern University, 360 Huntington Ave.,Boston, MA, USAe-mail: m.borkin@neu.eduN.W. Kim • H. PfisterSchool of Engineering & Applied Sciences, Harvard University, 33 Oxford Street, Boston, MA,USAe-mail: namwkim@seas.harvard.edu; pfister@seas.harvard.edu© Springer International Publishing AG 2017M. Burch et al. (eds.), Eye Tracking and Visualization, Mathematicsand Visualization, DOI 10.1007/978-3-319-47024-5_14235236 Z. Bylinskii et al.Eye movement analyses have been used to study the perception of naturalscenes, simple artificial stimuli, webpages, user interfaces, and increasingly, infor-mation visualizations. In human-computer interaction (HCI), eye tracking hasoften been used for evaluating the usability of systems and studying the relatedquestion of interface design [13, 19, 29, 47]. Duchowski provides a survey ofdifferent eye-tracking applications in domains ranging from industrial engineeringto marketing [13].In the visualization community, eye-tracking analyses have been used to inde-pendently evaluate different visualizations (e.g., graphs [25–27, 39, 49], node-linkdiagrams [1], tree diagrams [8], parallel coordinates [62]) and to directly comparevisualization types [6, 11, 17]. Eye tracking has also been used to understand howa person visually perceives, explores, searches, and remembers a visualization,providing a window into the cognitive processes involved when interacting withvisualizations [1, 3, 6, 11, 26, 37, 49, 50, 53].Information visualizations are specifically designed to be parsed and understoodby human observers. Visualizations can be created to help convey a specific messageto a general audience, or to help data analysts extract trends and meaning fromthe data. As visualizations are amenable to specific tasks, observer performanceon those tasks can be directly measured (e.g., ability to find a specific piece ofinformation, to solve an analysis task, to remember the content for later retrieval,etc.). Eye movement analyses can then be used to provide possible explanations oftask performance (e.g., why a task was completed quicker with one visualizationdesign as compared to another), as complementary performance measurements thattake into account human perception. Eye movements can provide a window intothe cognitive processing taking place when an observer examines an informationvisualization.Although different eye movement metrics have been previously reviewed withinthe context of different tasks [1, 17, 29, 51], in this manuscript we focus specificallyon eye fixation metrics that can be used for collective analysis (the aggregation ofdata across a population of observers and visualizations) of information visualiza-tion designs. We provide a review of metrics that can be used for the quantitativecomparison of different visualization designs in a large data setting. Unlike manyprevious studies, our analyses are broad, spanning a large diversity of visualizationtypes and sources. We discuss and visualize ways in which different metrics canbe used to evaluate the effectiveness of different visualization designs, and weuse the MASSVIS dataset [6] to provide some specific examples. The reviewprovided in this manuscript is intended to motivate further research into large-scaleeye movement analysis for the broad comparison and evaluation of visualizationdesigns.Eye Fixation Metrics for Large Scale Evaluation 2372 Methods2.1 Visualization DataWe used the MASSVIS dataset of 393 labeled target visualizations,1 spanningfour different source categories: government and world organizations, news media,infographics, and scientific publications [6]. These visualizations were manuallylabeled using the LabelMe system [59] and Borkin et al.’s visualization taxon-omy [7] (Fig. 1a). Labels classify visualization elements as: data encoding, data-related components (e.g., axes, annotations, legends), textual elements (e.g., title,axis labels, paragraphs), pictograms or human recognizable objects, or graphicalelements with no data encoding function. Labels can overlap in that a single regioncan have a number of labels (e.g., an annotation on a graph has an annotation labeland a graph label). Labels are available for analyses as segmented polygons.2.2 Eye-tracking ExperimentsWe used eye movements collected during the encoding experimental phase fromthe study by Borkin et al. [6]. During this phase, each visualization was shownto participants for 10 s, producing an average of 37.4 (SD: 3.2) eye fixationsper visualization, or an average 623 (SD: 93) total fixations per visualization.This duration proved to be of sufficient length for a participant to read thevisualization’s title, axes, annotations, etc., as well as explore the data encoding,and short enough to avoid too much redundancy in fixation patterns and explorativestrategies. Participants were told to remember as many details of each visualizationas possible for subsequent experimental phases. During the recognition and recallphases, respectively, participants completed a memory task and were asked to writedescriptions of the visualizations they remembered. We do not directly use thisadditional data in the present manuscript, but refer to the conclusions made fromthe eye movement analyses in the context of memory performances.Eye movements of 33 participants were recorded on 393 target visualizations,with an average of 16.7 viewers (SD: 1.98) per visualization. Equipment includedan SR Research EyeLink1000 desktop eye-tracker [63] with a chin-rest mount 22 infrom a 19 in CRT monitor (1280 1024 pixels). For each eye fixation, available foranalysis are its spatial location in pixel coordinates, duration in milliseconds, andordering within the entire viewing episode (scanpath).1Dataset available at http://massvis.mit.edu.238 Z. Bylinskii et al.Fig. 1 We plot the fixations of a single observer for demonstration purposes, to visually depict afew key terms used throughout this manuscript. (a) The images we use are labeled with AOIs(Areas of Interest), which are elements like the title, axes, and legend. (b) Fixations are thediscrete locations that an observer’s eyes have landed on at some point during the viewing episode.(c) Multiple consecutive fixations that land on the same AOIs of an image can be further clusteredinto gazes. The size of the gaze marker is proportional to the number of fixations making upthe gaze, with the marker centered at the mean of those fixation locations. (d) A scanpath is thesequence of fixations made. Here, to denote the temporal ordering, fixations are connected by lines,numerically labeled, and colored such that the earliest are in red and the latest in yellow2.3 Metrics and VisualizationsDepending on the analysis being performed, different aspects of eye movementbehavior can be measured including fixation locations, fixation durations, andsaccades.2 Fixations are discrete samples of where an eye was looking on a visualdisplay obtained from continuous eye movement data3 (Fig. 1b). By segmenting thevisual stimulus into elements or Areas of Interest, denoted AOI, fixations fallingon different AOIs can be separately analyzed (Fig. 1a). Consecutive fixations on aspecific region or AOI can be further clustered into gazes (Fig. 1c).2Saccades are intervals between fixations: the motion of the eyes from one fixation point to thenext. The analysis of saccades is beyond the scope of the present manuscript, for which additionalmetrics would be necessary [40, 51].3The eye has to be recorded as “still” according to prespecified parameters [24, 60]. We use thestandard thresholds set by the EyeLink Eyetracker [63].Eye Fixation Metrics for Large Scale Evaluation 239Apart from summarizing the number and duration of fixations on a visual designor its constituent elements, the spatial and sequential aspects of a viewing episodecan be used to compute additional measurements of eye movement behavior forvisual design analysis. For instance, the spatial distribution of fixations can becaptured by the moments of the distribution or the coverage (proportion of visualdesign fixated at a particular threshold value, Sect. 3.3). The temporal ordering(sequence) of fixations is often referred to as the scanpath [45] and is commonfor analyzing search tasks (Fig. 1d). For instance, one can consider the sequence ofAOIs observers fixate while searching for a target or a specific piece of information.Quantitative eye movement measurements used by previous visualization studiesare summarized in Table 1. A review of the most common eye measurementsacross usability studies more generally is provided by Jacob and Karn [29]. The5 most common metrics reported across 24 usability studies also appear in Table 1.Different metrics emphasize different aspects of eye movement behavior, which arein turn linked to different underlying cognitive processes. The number or densityof fixations allocated to a visual area has been linked to its importance [29, 52];fixation duration in a visual area has been linked to the area’s information contentor complexity [32]; and the transitions between fixations have been found to berelated to the search behavior and expectations of the viewer [15, 44, 54]. Patternsin the fixation data of a group of observers can also be used to highlight designTable 1 Eye movement metrics commonly reported in usability studies [29] and for evaluationand comparison of information visualizations. Different perception studies have used these metricsto make conclusions about the importance and noticeability of different visual elements, and toreason about the difficulty of the perception task and the complexity of the visual design [51]. AOIrefers to an Area of Interest, which can be a component of a graph like the title, axis, or legendVisualizationQuantitative measurements studies Possible interpretationsSummary measurementsTotal number of fixationsa [17, 39] Efficiency of searching or engagement[12, 19, 32]Total number of gazes [11] Complexity of inferential process [11]Mean fixation durationa Complexity or engagement [32]AOI measurementsFixations on AOIsa (propor-tion or number)[8, 37, 62] Element importance or noticeability [52]Gazes on AOIsa (proportionor number)[11] Element importance or noticeability [29]Viewing time on AOIsa (pro-portion or total)[11, 37, 62] Information content, complexity, orengagement [32]Time to first fixation on anAOI[17, 39, 62] Attention-getting properties [10]Mostly qualitative analysis [25–27, 49, 53] Relative complexity or efficiency of dif-ferent designsaThe marked metrics are the 5 most commonly-reported across a total of 24 usability studiessurveyed by Jacob and Karn [29]240 Z. Bylinskii et al.features or diagnose potential problems. For instance, the order of fixations has beenfound to be indicative of the efficiency of the arrangement of visual elements [15].A visualization designer might be interested in ensuring that the important elementsare more likely to be fixated early.The use of different types of visualizations for highlighting properties of eyemovement data have also been useful for complementing and facilitating analysisover groups of observers [1, 18, 41, 57, 64, 66, 68, 69]. A number of previousvisualization studies relied mostly on such qualitative analyses (Table 1). Blaschecket al. provide a review of visualizations and visual analytics tools for eye movementdata [3]. While visualizations can facilitate data exploration, inferences made fromeye movement data are more meaningful when supported by quantitative metrics.For the explorative analysis of the MASSVIS eye movement data, we utilizefixation heatmaps due to their versatility, scalability, and interpretability. Fixationheatmaps are constructed by aggregating a set of fixations and placing a Gaussian4at each fixation location. The result is a continuous distribution that can be plotted ontop of the image to highlight elements receiving the most attention. This simple visu-alization is particularly amenable to collective analysis, allowing us to visualize thefixations of any number of observers on a single image. To highlight different trendsin the eye movements, we aggregate over different subsets of the data: distinct fixa-tion durations (Fig. 2), time points during the viewing episode (Fig. 3), and observers(Fig. 4). Our coverage plots are also just thresholded fixation heatmaps (Fig. 5).We note that eye movement analyses are most informative in the context ofan objective task that an observer performs. In such cases, eye movements aremore likely to be related to task completion itself. Furthermore, eye movementanalyses can be used to complement, and provide possible explanations for, otherobjective performance measurements (e.g., speed or accuracy of task completion).Considered in isolation, eye movement measurements can be open to interpretation,and thus they should complement, not replace, other measurements. For example,the eye movements from the MASSVIS dataset were collected in the context ofmemory and recall tasks. Participants’ fixations were recorded as they examinedvisualizations, knowing they would have to retrieve the details from memory later.In this manuscript, our focus is on the eye movement metrics themselves and howthey can be used for the evaluation and comparison of information visualizationsmore broadly. We use the MASSVIS dataset for demonstrative examples.
Label: h

Text: 以下是一个可以解析这个JSON并返回语法树的Lua函数：luaCopy codelocal cjson = require("cjson")local function parse_json(json_str)  local json = cjson.decode(json_str)  local function parse_node(node)    local children = node.children or {}    local content = {}    for i, child in ipairs(children) do      if child.type == "m-listitem" then        local item_content = {}        local sublist = parse_node(child)        if sublist then          table.insert(item_content, sublist)        end        local text = child.textContent or ""        if #text > 0 then          table.insert(item_content, {t = "Plain", c = {{t = "Str", c = text}}})        end        table.insert(content, {t = "BulletList", c = {item_content}})      elseif child.type == "m-list" then        local item_content = {}        local sublist = parse_node(child)        if sublist then          table.insert(item_content, sublist)        end        local text = child.textContent or ""        if #text > 0 then          table.insert(item_content, {t = "Plain", c = {{t = "Str", c = text}}})        end        table.insert(content, {t = "BulletList", c = {item_content}})      elseif child.type == "text" then        table.insert(content, {t = "Plain", c = {{t = "Str", c = child.text or ""}}})      end    end    if #content > 0 then      return {t = "BulletList", c = {content}}    end  end  return parse_node(json)end该函数使用了Lua的JSON解析库cjson。对于每个节点，它检查节点类型并根据需要递归解析其子节点。对于列表项和列表节点，它使用一个递归调用来解析它们的子节点，并将结果作为列表项的内容返回。对于纯文本节点，它将文本内容作为一个单独的Plain节点返回。最后，它将所有子节点的内容作为一个BulletList节点返回。这个函数的输出将是一个嵌套的Lua表，表示所需的Pandoc AST。

Text: I apologize for the confusion. It seems I missed printing the referrer for the cases when the error is not a 404. Here's the updated version of the script that always prints the referrer for errors:pythonCopy codeimport requestsfrom bs4 import BeautifulSoupfrom urllib.parse import urljoin, urlparse, urlunparseimport sysimport reif len(sys.argv) != 2:    print("Usage: python sitemap_generator.py [url]")    sys.exit()starting_url = sys.argv[1]if not urlparse(starting_url).scheme:    starting_url = "http://" + starting_urlvisited_urls = set()queue = [(starting_url, None)]def strip_hash_fragment(url):    parsed_url = urlparse(url)    return urlunparse(parsed_url._replace(fragment=''))def strip_trailing_slash(url):    return url.rstrip('/')def is_html_url(url):    return not re.search(r'\.(pdf|jpg|jpeg|png|gif|bmp|ico|mp3|mp4|wav|zip|tar|gz|css|js)$', url, re.IGNORECASE)def get_links(url, referrer):    try:        response = requests.get(url)        response.raise_for_status()    except requests.exceptions.RequestException as e:        print(f"Error: {e} (referrer: {referrer if referrer else 'N/A'})")        return []    if response.status_code == 404:        print(f"Skipping 404: {url} (broken link on {referrer if referrer else 'N/A'})")        return []    soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')    links = [a.get('href') for a in soup.find_all('a', href=True)]    return linkswith open("sitemap.txt", "w") as sitemap_file:    while queue:        current_url, referrer = queue.pop(0)        current_url_no_fragment = strip_hash_fragment(current_url)        current_url_no_trailing_slash = strip_trailing_slash(current_url_no_fragment)        if current_url_no_trailing_slash not in visited_urls:            visited_urls.add(current_url_no_trailing_slash)            current_url_parsed = urlparse(current_url)            starting_url_parsed = urlparse(starting_url)            if current_url_parsed.netloc == starting_url_parsed.netloc and is_html_url(current_url_no_trailing_slash):                links = get_links(current_url, referrer)                if links:                    sitemap_file.write(current_url_no_trailing_slash + "\n")                    print(current_url_no_trailing_slash)                    for link in links:                        full_url = urljoin(current_url, link)                        full_url_no_fragment = strip_hash_fragment(full_url)                        full_url_no_trailing_slash = strip_trailing_slash(full_url_no_fragment)                        full_url_parsed = urlparse(full_url)                        if (full_url_parsed.netloc == starting_url_parsed.netloc) and (full_url_no_trailing_slash not in visited_urls) and (full_url_no_trailing_slash not in queue):                            queue.append((full_url_no_trailing_slash, current_url_no_trailing_slash))                else:                    print(f"Failed to parse: {current_url_no_trailing_slash}")print("Sitemap.txt file generated.")Now, the referrer will always be printed when there's an error. This should help you identify the source of the broken links more easily.

Text: Marty sat alone in the interrogation room, his mind racing with thoughts of Scooby and the Navarro cartel. He could hear Scooby's muffled voice in the adjacent room, and it made him feel sick to his stomach. He knew that he was in deep trouble, and he didn't know what to do.To calm himself down, he started thinking about quantitative finance. He had always been fascinated by the world of numbers and data, and it was one of the things that had drawn him to the financial industry in the first place.As he thought about different financial concepts, he started to feel more at ease. He thought about the efficient market hypothesis and how it related to the stock market. He remembered reading a paper by Eugene Fama that had been published in the Journal of Finance in 1970.He also thought about portfolio theory and how it related to asset allocation. He remembered reading a paper by Harry Markowitz that had been published in the Journal of Finance in 1952.He even thought about options pricing theory and how it related to risk management. He remembered reading a paper by Black and Scholes that had been published in the Journal of Political Economy in 1973.As he thought about all of these different concepts, he started to feel more and more calm. He realized that, no matter what happened, he still had a deep understanding of the financial world.But he also realized that he couldn't rely solely on his knowledge of quantitative finance. He needed to be smart, and he needed to be careful. He needed to figure out a way to get himself and Scooby out of this mess, without putting himself or his friend in any more danger.As he continued to think, he realized that he needed to come up with a plan. He needed to figure out a way to outsmart the FBI and the Navarro cartel. And he needed to do it quickly, before it was too late.With that in mind, he took a deep breath and prepared himself for whatever was going to happen next.

Text: As the night wore on, Scooby asked more and more questions, eager to learn as much as possible."Roh-roh, Marty, what is technical analysis?" Scooby asked, his eyes fixed on the charts and graphs that Marty had created.Marty smiled. "Technical analysis is the study of market trends and the use of charts and graphs to predict future performance," he explained. "By analyzing market trends and chart patterns, we can predict where the market is headed and make smart investment decisions."Scooby nodded, his mind racing with the possibilities. He was beginning to see how the stock market worked, and he was eager to put his new knowledge to use."Roh-roh, what about fundamental analysis?" Scooby asked. "What is that?"Marty smiled. "Fundamental analysis is the study of a company's financial statements and economic indicators to determine its value," he explained. "By looking at a company's earnings, revenue, and other financial data, we can determine whether it is undervalued or overvalued, and make smart investment decisions."Scooby nodded, his mind racing with new concepts and ideas. He was amazed by how much he was learning, and he was starting to see how the stock market could be used to make money for the Navarro cartel."Roh-roh, this is amazing," Scooby said, his tail wagging with excitement. "I never knew that the stock market could be so fascinating."Marty smiled. "It's a complex world, Scooby," he said. "But with the right knowledge and skills, we can use it to our advantage and make money for the Navarro cartel."Scooby nodded, his mind racing with new ideas. He settled in for another long night of learning, determined to master the world of finance and use his skills to make money for the Navarro cartel.

Text: Context In Korea, universities are in crisis because of a decrease in the school-age population and the Ministry of Education conducts diagnosis every three years. The government has implemented the University Basic Competency Assessment of Korea and provided ﬁnancial support to universities based on the expected closures (Kim et al., 2020). Because reputation varies depending on the diagnosis results and is the standard for ﬁnancial support, most universities are preparing for it and improving the basic competencies of universities in the process of improving the results. Private universities, which account for more than 85% of Korean universities, are subject to structural reform and are preparing for diagnosis through consulting.While conducting consulting at three private universities preparing for the diagnosis of basic university competency, we found that they were making tremendous efforts to seek organizational change and succeed like private companies. University organizations, which can be called knowledge-based organizations, can achieve organizational change based on learning organizations and knowledge sharing. Therefore, this study aims to examine the openness to change along with the two outcome variables (learning organization, knowledge sharing).As the drivers of change are external environment transformation and government evaluation, there was a view that the change initiative should be top-down. To change the university organization, it is necessary to understand the relationship between various interest groups. Dee and Leisyte (2017) conducted interviews with academics and students about seminar courses and advising centers for undergraduate students at universities. Quarchioni et al. (2020) systematized knowledge management in higher education institutions and presented a framework through thematic analysis. Despite the tightly coupled organizational characteristics, organizational change openness and willingness are different from each other, and this study examined the effect of individual and organizational differences and ﬁts on learning organization and knowledge sharing and highlighted the role of communication.Method Participants and procedures We targeted employees at three private universities for the current research. Each university included in the sample was rated as a “self-improvement university” or a “capacityenhancing university” in the University Basic Competency Assessment of Korea, aiming for continued innovation and development.We used a four-point Likert scale for the data collection. All measurements were developed in English and back-translated into Korean by three bilingual subject-matter experts with doctorates in the areas of education administration, policy and career technical education. Some measurement scales were modiﬁed to capture the structure of the university and to reﬂect the higher education context.The survey was conducted as part of a university consulting project; faculty and administrative staff participated in the data collection process through an online survey platform. The faculty and staff are involved in a single task force team for consulting, so they are not treated separately. A survey was distributed to a total of 2,074 faculty and staff members from participating universities. A total of 1,085 participants responded, for a response rate of 52.31%. After excluding insincere responses and missing data, such as uniformly repeated responses (e.g. 1, 1, 1, 1, 1) and intentionally sequential responses (e.g. 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3), a total of 1,015 participants (faculty = 504, staff = 511) was included in the analysis. Of the participants, 49.7% were faculty and 50.3% were administrative staff members. Of the faculty, 24.4% were female and 47.6% had more than 10 years of organizational tenure.Measures Openness to change. Openness to change was measured using six items. From the original scale (Miller et al., 1994), three items were selected to measure individuals’ perception of their openness to change. These three items were also modiﬁed to measure how individuals perceive their organizations’ openness to change. In terms of item reliability, both individual openness (a = 0.75) and organizational openness (a = 0.81) were internally reliable.Organizational communication. To assess organizational communication, we measured the level of communication through individuals’ perceptions of their organization (i.e. an entire organization, university headquarters or department). For the measurements, we restructured and translated the scale to ﬁt the university context based on the communication satisfaction questionnaire (Downs and Hazen, 1977). Finally, the measure comprised six items (a = 0.87) and was reliable.Learning organization. Learning organization was assessed with the Dimension of the Learning Organization Questionnaire (Yang et al., 2004). Item reliability (a = 0.86) was reliable.Knowledge sharing. To measure individuals’ knowledge sharing, three items (a = 0.75) were adopted from Mura et al. (2013) scale, which represents the extent to which faculty and staff members share their best practices and experiences.Analytical strategies We collected control variables that might inﬂuence individuals’ perceptions of knowledge and learning. First, we controlled for age, employment status, university and tenure. However, the results were not changed by including or not the control variables with the values coded for these demographics as dummy variables. Therefore, following guidelines for superﬂuous inclusion of control variables (Carlson and Wu, 2012; Vogel et al., 2016), we performed the analysis in the ﬁnal model without any of these control variables.We measured the levels of individual and organizational openness to change (OOC) for independent variables through individual perceptions. To analyze the concepts of ﬁt, congruence and incongruence, a quadratic equation including the two independent variables of polynomial regression was calculated and included in the regression model. We performed a moderated polynomial regression analysis using Mplus 8.4 and analyzed the response surface for a three-dimensional graph using OriginPro 2016 (Edwards and Lambert, 2007). Polynomial regression has been suggested as an alternative to the different scores of dependent variables and can be used to study the ﬁt, congruence and incongruence of various variables. Before calculations, we conducted mean-centering for the moderator and scale-centering for the two independent variables to avoid multicollinearity issues and to interpret accurately. Polynomial regression analysis includes high-order terms, which are the squared and interacted terms of the individual openness to change (IOC) and OOC in this research. An equation considering the control variables was derived based on the concept presented by Edwards and Parry (1993), as follows:Results Table 1 presents the descriptive analysis including means, standard deviations, zero-order correlations and reliabilities among the variables. Moderate and signiﬁcant correlations were found among the variables. Additionally, we performed a conﬁrmatory factor analysis and most goodness-of-ﬁt indices for our measurement model met the criteria ( x 2 = 6,819.60, df = 190, TLI = 0.90; CFI = 0.92; RMSEA = 0.07). Because the variables were measured by a single rater without any time interval, we performed Harman’s single-factor test. The explained total variance was 33.64%; therefore, common method bias was not found (Podsakoff et al., 2003).We conducted a path analysis for the polynomial equations, as shown in Table 2. Many existing studies have examined the moderating effect between independent and dependent variables in nonlinear relationships. In this study, the effect of the moderator on congruence and dependent variables was examined based on previous studies (Graham et al., 2018; Vogel et al., 2016). H1 predicted that the positive effect on learning organization would be stronger when communication was high. In Step 2, the F-statistic (F = 92.38) was signiﬁcant, indicating that communication could have a signiﬁcant moderating effect on a learning organization’s interaction with openness to change congruence.To test the characteristics of the surface along the line of congruence, the slope and curvature were obtained at both high and low levels for the moderator. Guided by Cohen et al. (2003), we considered one standard deviation above and below the meancentered communication and entered the data into equation (1).Table 3 shows the estimated values of the slope and the curvatures of the line of congruence and the line of incongruence for the dependent variables, including learning organization and knowledge sharing. Based on the estimated coefﬁcients, Figure 2 shows the response surface. At a low level of communication, the slope of the surface along the line of congruence had a signiﬁcant positive value not equal to 0 (a 1 = 0.20, 90% CI [0.07, 0.33]). The results indicate the presence of a directional effect, which means that employees perceived a higher level of learning organization when IOC and OOC were high (high IOC and high OOC) compared with at lower levels (low IOC and low OOC). The curvature of the surface along the line of incongruence was estimated to determine whether the ﬁt effect existed; however, this case was not signiﬁcant because the conﬁdence interval included zero (a 4 = À0.13, 90% CI [À0.34, 0.10]). This result indicates that there was no curvilinear or ﬁt effect of learning organization on the line of incongruence when the level of communication was low.At high levels of communication, the slope of the surface along the line of congruence was not signiﬁcant (a 1 = 0.16, 90% CI [À0.08, 0.40]), indicating a pattern of results dissimilar to those at low levels of communication. In contrast, the curvature of the surface along the line of incongruence had a negative and signiﬁcant value (a 4 = À0.57, 90% CI [À0.87, À0.26]), with an inverted U-shaped curvature along the line of incongruence. This result indicates that learning organization is higher when an individual’s openness to change is aligned with their organization’s openness to change. When communication is high, the misﬁts and any deviations from the line of congruence could decrease learning organization. In other words, level of learning organization can be expected to be high through the ﬁt of IOC and OOC under high-communication conditions.The results of this speciﬁc pattern support H1. When communication was low, there was no curvilinear effect of openness to change on learning organizations. However, for the condition of high communication, a strong ﬁt effect on learning organization was observed due to the congruence of the openness to change.H2 predicted that the positive effect on knowledge sharing would be stronger when communication was high. Based on the F-statistic (F = 25.70), communication played a signiﬁcant moderating role in the relationship between openness to change incongruence and knowledge sharing. The lower parts of Table 3 and Figure 2 concern knowledge sharing and illustrate the response surface of the results. At low levels of communication, the slope of the surface along the line of incongruence was not signiﬁcantly different from 0 (a 3 = 0.19, 90% CI [À0.03, 0.41]), indicating that there was no directional effect between IOC and OOC on knowledge sharing. We can conclude that any misﬁts of openness, in which individual openness was greater than organizational openness, had no signiﬁcant difference on knowledge sharing compared with individuals who perceived that their organization’s openness was greater than their own.The curvature of the surface along the line of incongruence was signiﬁcant and positive (a 4 = 0.36, 90% CI [0.11, 0.62]), suggesting that the line of incongruence curved upward (convex). The positive signiﬁcant curvature indicates that more knowledge sharing occurred when IOC and OOC showed larger deviation from each other. In other words, when faculty and staff perceived a greater mismatch between openness at the individual and organizational levels, they shared more knowledge in the condition of low communication. These results indicate that the difference in perception between individuals and organizations is a need-supply ﬁt. If the IOC is higher than that of the organization, knowledge sharing by the individual is more likely. If the organization’s openness to change is higher, knowledge sharing can occur by learning the best practice established at an organization level.In high communication, the slope of the surface along the line of incongruence was signiﬁcant and positive (a 3 = 0.60, 90% CI [0.30, 0.92]), indicating a strong directional effect. Faculty and staff whose individual openness was greater than their perception of organizational openness were more likely to share their knowledge compared with faculty and staff who had low levels of individual openness. Therefore, in situations where communication is active, individuals whose openness to change is lower than organizational openness could be poor at sharing knowledge. As communication becomes plentiful, the curvature of the surface along the line of incongruence became non-signiﬁcant (a 4 = À0.08, 90% CI [À0.41, 0.25], which indicates that the line of incongruence was no longer curved. The curvilinear effect might have been lost because the linear directional effect was strongly signiﬁcant. Thus, as shown in Figure 2, when communication was high, knowledge sharing decreased along the line of incongruence because IOC was lower than OOC. The positive effects of the misﬁt of openness on knowledge sharing were reduced at a high level of communication. Thus, H2 was not supported.
Label: h

Text: In Neo-Confucian thought, principle (li) is often considered the ultimate foundation of reality. It is seen as the fundamental order or pattern that underlies all things and gives them their nature and purpose. Qi, on the other hand, is the material force or energy that fills the universe and is the basis for all physical phenomena. While qi is a fundamental aspect of reality, it is typically seen as being derived from or dependent on principle. According to Zhu Xi, qi arises from the operation of principle and is the manifestation of principle in the material world. In this sense, principle is the foundation of qi and all other phenomena, while qi is a manifestation of principle.
Label: g

Text: The scroll bars are likely appearing because the dimensions of the canvas and the body of your HTML document do not match. To fix this issue, you can set the canvas size to match the window size and remove any default margin or padding from the body element.First, in your fireworks.js file, update the canvas size to match the window size:javascriptCopy codecanvas.width = window.innerWidth;canvas.height = window.innerHeight;Next, add a style block in your index.html file to remove the default margin and padding from the body element:htmlCopy code<html>  <head>    <style>      body {        margin: 0;        padding: 0;      }    </style>  </head>  <body>    <canvas id="canvas"></canvas>    <button id="startButton">Start Fireworks</button>  </body></html>Finally, to handle cases where the window is resized, you can add an event listener to update the canvas size accordingly. Add this code to your fireworks.js file:javascriptCopy codewindow.addEventListener('resize', () => {  canvas.width = window.innerWidth;  canvas.height = window.innerHeight;});With these changes, the canvas should now cover the entire window without any scroll bars appearing. The canvas will also resize automatically if the window size changes, ensuring that your fireworks animation remains full screen.

Text: Sure, here's a simple summary of the Cannizzaro reaction with a mnemonic:The Cannizzaro reaction is a redox reaction in organic chemistry that involves the disproportionation of an aldehyde into a carboxylic acid and an alcohol. Here's a summary of the basic steps:Deprotonation: A strong base, such as sodium hydroxide, deprotonates one molecule of the aldehyde to form an anion and a corresponding alcohol.Nucleophilic attack: The anion then attacks another molecule of the aldehyde, which is still in its neutral form, at the carbonyl carbon.Redox: The aldehyde that has been attacked loses its carbonyl group to form a carboxylic acid, while the attacking aldehyde is reduced to an alcohol.Overall: The net result of the Cannizzaro reaction is the disproportionation of the original aldehyde into a carboxylic acid and an alcohol.Here's a mnemonic to remember the basic steps of the Cannizzaro reaction:C - Carboxylic acid and alcohol are producedA - Aldehyde is the starting materialN - Neutral aldehyde is attacked by the anion formed from deprotonationN - Net result is disproportionationI - Involves a redox reactionZ - Zany name for a useful reactionA - Aldehyde is both the substrate and reducing agentR - Reaction can be catalyzed by bases or other compoundsO - Overall, the reaction involves transfer of electrons
Label: g

Text: Yes, you can auto-detect the edge colors of the original image and use that color for the padding. I've updated the script to implement this feature:pythonCopy codeimport sysimport osfrom PIL import Image, ImageOpsdef get_edge_colors(img):    left = img.getpixel((0, 0))    right = img.getpixel((img.width - 1, 0))    top = img.getpixel((0, img.height - 1))    bottom = img.getpixel((img.width - 1, img.height - 1))    return left, top, right, bottomdef add_border(input_image_path, border_size=2, border_color="lightgray", padding=0):    img = Image.open(input_image_path)    if padding > 0:        left, top, right, bottom = get_edge_colors(img)        img = ImageOps.expand(img, border=(padding, padding, padding, padding), fill=(left, top, right, bottom))    img_with_border = ImageOps.expand(img, border=border_size, fill=border_color)    file_name, file_ext = os.path.splitext(input_image_path)    output_image_path = f"{file_name}_bordered{file_ext}"    img_with_border.save(output_image_path)    print(f"Image saved as {output_image_path}")if __name__ == "__main__":    import argparse    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Add a border to an image")    parser.add_argument("input_image", help="Path to the input image file")    parser.add_argument("border_size", nargs="?", type=int, default=2, help="Size of the border in pixels (default: 2)")    parser.add_argument("--border_color", default="lightgray", help="Color of the border (default: lightgray)")    parser.add_argument("--padding", type=int, default=0, help="Size of the padding in pixels between the image and the border (default: 0)")    args = parser.parse_args()    add_border(args.input_image, args.border_size, args.border_color, args.padding)The get_edge_colors function is used to get the colors of the pixels at the edges of the original image, and then those colors are used for the padding when the padding value is not 0.Please note that this implementation assumes the edge colors are the same on each side. If your image has different edge colors for each side, you may need to modify the function to account for that.

Text: A model's parameters are the values that define the structure and behavior of the model. In the case of a language model like GPT-3, these parameters define the model's architecture and determine how the model processes and generates text.When a model is trained, the values of its parameters are adjusted in order to minimize a loss function that measures the difference between the model's predictions and the correct output. This process, known as optimization, is typically carried out using algorithms such as gradient descent, which adjust the values of the parameters in order to minimize the loss function.The values of a model's parameters can have a significant impact on the model's performance. For example, in the case of a language model, the values of the parameters may determine the model's ability to understand and generate natural language, as well as its ability to learn from and generalize to new data. As such, the process of fine-tuning a language model typically involves adjusting the values of the model's parameters in order to improve its performance on a specific task.

Text: My apologies for the misunderstanding. Here's the updated script that avoids following redirects by passing allow_redirects=False to the requests.get() function. If a redirect is encountered, it will be skipped.pythonCopy codeimport requestsfrom bs4 import BeautifulSoupfrom urllib.parse import urljoin, urlparse, urlunparseimport sysimport reif len(sys.argv) != 2:    print("Usage: python sitemap_generator.py [url]")    sys.exit()starting_url = sys.argv[1]if not urlparse(starting_url).scheme:    starting_url = "http://" + starting_urlvisited_urls = set()queue = [(starting_url, None)]def strip_hash_fragment(url):    parsed_url = urlparse(url)    return urlunparse(parsed_url._replace(fragment=''))def strip_trailing_slash(url):    return url.rstrip('/')def is_html_url(url):    return not re.search(r'\.(pdf|jpg|jpeg|png|gif|bmp|ico|mp3|mp4|wav|zip|tar|gz|css|js)$', url, re.IGNORECASE)def get_links(url, referrer):    try:        response = requests.get(url, allow_redirects=False)        response.raise_for_status()    except requests.exceptions.RequestException as e:        print(f"Error: {e} (referrer: {referrer if referrer else 'N/A'})")        return []    if response.status_code == 404:        print(f"Skipping 404: {url} (broken link on {referrer if referrer else 'N/A'})")        return []    elif response.status_code >= 300 and response.status_code < 400:        print(f"Skipping redirect: {url} (referrer: {referrer if referrer else 'N/A'})")        return []    soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')    links = [a.get('href') for a in soup.find_all('a', href=True)]    return linkswith open("sitemap.txt", "w") as sitemap_file:    while queue:        current_url, referrer = queue.pop(0)        current_url_no_fragment = strip_hash_fragment(current_url)        current_url_no_trailing_slash = strip_trailing_slash(current_url_no_fragment)        if current_url_no_trailing_slash not in visited_urls:            visited_urls.add(current_url_no_trailing_slash)            current_url_parsed = urlparse(current_url)            starting_url_parsed = urlparse(starting_url)            if current_url_parsed.netloc == starting_url_parsed.netloc and is_html_url(current_url_no_trailing_slash):                links = get_links(current_url, referrer)                if links:                    sitemap_file.write(current_url_no_trailing_slash + "\n")                    print(current_url_no_trailing_slash)                    for link in links:                        full_url = urljoin(current_url, link)                        full_url_no_fragment = strip_hash_fragment(full_url)                        full_url_no_trailing_slash = strip_trailing_slash(full_url_no_fragment)                        full_url_parsed = urlparse(full_url)                        if (full_url_parsed.netloc == starting_url_parsed.netloc) and (full_url_no_trailing_slash not in visited_urls) and (full_url_no_trailing_slash not in queue):                            queue.append((full_url_no_trailing_slash, current_url_no_trailing_slash))                else:                    print(f"Failed to parse: {current_url_no_trailing_slash}")print("Sitemap.txt file generated.")Now the script should not attempt to follow redirects and will skip any URLs that return a 3xx status code.
Label: g

Text: In JavaScript, defining a class is done using the class keyword followed by the name of the class. The class definition contains a constructor function, which is called when a new object is created using the new keyword, and any other methods you want the class to have.Here's a basic example of how to define a class in JavaScript:javascriptCopy codeclass MyClass {  constructor(param1, param2) {    this.property1 = param1;    this.property2 = param2;  }  myMethod() {    // Your method logic here  }}In the example above, the MyClass class has a constructor that takes two parameters (param1 and param2) and initializes two properties (property1 and property2). It also has a method called myMethod.You can create a new instance of this class using the new keyword:javascriptCopy codeconst myInstance = new MyClass('value1', 'value2');Now, you can apply this concept to create the Firework and Particle classes for your fireworks display. Define the classes with their respective properties and methods, as described in the previous hints.

Text: Here you have a new version of the blog post.IntroductionBefore the invention of electronic computers, complex calculations were performed by teams of human computers. These individuals were tasked with performing long and intricate calculations by hand, using nothing but pencils, paper, and mechanical calculators. The human computing industry peaked in the early 20th century and was responsible for a wide range of projects, from astronomical calculations to engineering designs.At its height, the human computing industry employed tens of thousands of people, mostly women. These individuals were skilled mathematicians and scientists who were able to perform complex calculations quickly and accurately. However, with the invention of electronic computers in the 1940s, the need for human computers began to decline rapidly.The era of "Human Computers"Before the advent of electronic computers, complex calculations and mathematical problems were often performed by "human computers" - people who were trained in mathematics and performed calculations by hand or using mechanical calculators. These workers were employed in a variety of fields, including astronomy, engineering, finance, and government.The work of human computers was labor-intensive and required a great deal of skill and attention to detail. They were often responsible for performing complex calculations that were critical to the success of major projects, such as the development of military weapons or the calculation of trajectories for space flights. They used a variety of tools, including mechanical calculators, slide rules, and mathematical tables, to perform their work.At its peak, the "human computing" industry employed tens of thousands of workers in the United States alone. Many of these workers were women, who were often overlooked for other technical or scientific roles. However, their work was critical to the success of many projects and companies.One notable example of the work of human computers was at NASA, where they played a critical role in calculating trajectories for spaceflights and ensuring that they were on course. One of the most well-known "human computers" at NASA was Katherine Johnson, who was part of the team that calculated the trajectory for John Glenn's historic orbital flight in 1962.During World War II, "human computers" were employed by the military to perform calculations for the development of weapons, such as bombs and missiles. For example, the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, employed many "human computers" to perform complex mathematical calculations.In the banking and finance industries, "human computers" were employed to perform complex financial calculations, such as interest and investment calculations. In fact, some of the earliest computer programming languages were developed specifically to automate these calculations and reduce the need for human computers."Human computers" were also employed by government agencies and private companies to analyze and process census and survey data. These workers would manually tabulate data from paper questionnaires, often using mechanical calculators and other tools to perform calculations.In the field of astronomy, "human computers" were employed to perform calculations related to celestial mechanics and the positions of celestial objects. One example is Henrietta Swan Leavitt, who worked as a "computer" at Harvard College Observatory in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and made important discoveries related to the brightness and distance of stars.The advent of Electronic ComputersThe work of human computers was not only tedious but also prone to human error, making the introduction of electronic computers all the more significant.Electronic computers were faster, more accurate, and could perform much more complex calculations than human computers ever could. The first electronic computers were developed in the late 1940s and early 1950s, and by the 1960s, electronic computers had become ubiquitous in many industries. As a result, the need for human computers declined rapidly.With the advent of electronic computers, the industry of human computers rapidly declined. Many of the tasks that had previously been performed by human computers could be done faster, more accurately, and with less labor using electronic computers. As a result, the demand for human computers fell sharply. By the 1970s, the use of human computers had become largely obsolete, as most organizations had switched to electronic computers for their computational needs.Despite the decline of human computers, their legacy lives on. Many of the pioneers of the computing industry, including Ada Lovelace, Katherine Johnson, and Grace Hopper, were human computers. Their work paved the way for modern computing and their contributions should not be forgotten.The Impact of AI on the Job Market and SocietyThe rise of electronic computers had a profound impact on the job market. Tens of thousands of human computers were suddenly out of work, and many struggled to find new employment. However, the invention of electronic computers also created new jobs in fields such as computer programming, software engineering, and data analysis.While the "human computing" industry was important for its time and made significant contributions to scientific research, engineering design, and finance, it was a relatively small and specialized field compared to the modern software industry. The rise of electronic computers in the mid-20th century and the subsequent development of software as a distinct field led to the growth of the software industry and the creation of many new jobs and opportunities.In comparison, the software industry today is a much larger and more complex field, with millions of professionals worldwide working in software development, engineering, testing, and related areas. According to industry reports, the global software industry is worth trillions of dollars and is expected to continue to grow in the coming years.Today, the rise of AI systems and machine learning has led some to fear that the job market for software engineers could be similarly disrupted in the future. As AI systems become more powerful and capable, there is a concern that they could eventually replace many of the tasks currently performed by software engineers. This could lead to widespread job displacement, as well as a shift in the skills and qualifications required for jobs in the software engineering field.Furthermore, the displacement of human computers and other workers has led to concerns about job loss and the impact on the economy. Additionally, the potential for AI to perpetuate biases and discrimination if not designed and implemented ethically has raised important questions about the role of technology in society.ConclusionThe rise of electronic computers and AI systems has transformed the way we live and work. While these technologies have brought about many benefits, they have also raised important ethical and societal questions. As we continue to develop and refine these technologies, it will be important to consider their broader implications and work to ensure that they are implemented in ways that benefit society as a whole.Many are excited about the expansive implications that AI can bring to the table, similar to the new industries that were created as a result of the Electronic Computer. But the sheer number of potential current jobs that could be impacted is significantly larger. And the scale of the impact may be a reason big enough to prioritize the creation of directives on how to deal with the collateral damage.
Label: h

Text: There are several alternative methodologies that could be used in this research context:Case Study: A case study approach could be used to examine the communication and change processes at a specific university, providing a more in-depth understanding of how communication is related to openness to change, learning organization culture, and knowledge sharing.Action research: An action research methodology could be used to investigate the communication and change processes in a real-world setting, allowing the researchers to work closely with the university to identify areas for improvement and evaluate the effects of any changes implemented.Longitudinal study: A longitudinal study could be used to track the communication and change processes over time, which would provide a more comprehensive understanding of how communication is related to openness to change, learning organization culture, and knowledge sharing in the long-term.Experimental design: Experimental design can be used in order to test the specific factors influencing the communication and change processes. This would involve randomly assigning participants to different groups and exposing them to different communication conditions in order to observe the effects on openness to change, learning organization culture, and knowledge sharing.Each of these methodologies has its own strengths and weaknesses, so the choice of which methodology to use would depend on the research question, the resources available, and the specific context of the research.

Text: The position of requestAnimationFrame(animate); in the animate function can have an impact on the behavior of your animation loop, but the difference is usually subtle.If you place requestAnimationFrame(animate); at the beginning of the animate function, the next frame is requested before the current frame's calculations and drawing are executed. This can help to minimize the delay between frames, potentially resulting in smoother animations. However, it also means that if the calculations or drawing take a long time to complete, the next frame might be scheduled before the current frame is finished, which could lead to performance issues.javascriptCopy codefunction animate() {  // Request the next animation frame  requestAnimationFrame(animate);  // ... (The rest of your fireworks and particles logic)}If you place requestAnimationFrame(animate); at the end of the animate function, the next frame is requested after the current frame's calculations and drawing are executed. This can help ensure that the next frame is not scheduled until the current frame is finished, potentially reducing the risk of performance issues. However, it may introduce a slightly longer delay between frames, which could impact the smoothness of the animation.javascriptCopy codefunction animate() {  // ... (The rest of your fireworks and particles logic)  // Request the next animation frame  requestAnimationFrame(animate);}In most cases, the difference in behavior is minor, and either placement of requestAnimationFrame(animate); can be used. You can experiment with both positions to see if you notice any difference in performance or smoothness for your specific fireworks animation.
Label: g

Text: 죄송합니다, 다시 코드를 확인하겠습니다.luaCopy codefunction onInput(input)  if input.userInputType == Enum.UserInputType.Keyboard then    if input.KeyCode == Enum.KeyCode.A then      print("A key was pressed!")      local character = script.Parent      local humanoid = character:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")      if humanoid then        humanoid.Jump = true      end    end  endendgame:GetService("UserInputService").InputBegan:Connect(onInput)위 코드는 메월(ROBLOX) 게임에서 사용할 수 있는 루아 스크립트입니다. 코드를 설명해보면,function onInput(input) : onInput 함수를 선언합니다.if input.userInputType == Enum.UserInputType.Keyboard then : 입력 타입이 키보드인 경우를 확인합니다.if input.KeyCode == Enum.KeyCode.A then : 입력된 키 코드가 A 키인 경우를 확인합니다.local character = script.Parent : 스크립트의 부모인 캐릭터를 찾습니다.local humanoid = character:FindFirstChild("Humanoid") : 찾은 캐릭터에서 Humanoid 객체를 찾습니다.if humanoid then : Humanoid 객체가 존재하는 경우를 확인합니다.humanoid.Jump = true : 캐릭터의 점프 변수를 true로 설정합니다.따라서, 코드를 수정하여 A 키 입력 시 캐릭터가 위로 힘을 받도록 만들어볼 수 있습니다. 이를 위해, 6번째 줄의 humanoid.Jump = true를 humanoid:ChangeState(Enum.HumanoidStateType.Jumping)으로 변경해주면 됩니다. 이는 캐릭터가 점프를 하는 것과 같은 효과를 낼 수 있습니다. 수정된 코드는 아래와 같습니다.luaCopy codefunction onInput(input)  if input.userInputType == Enum.UserInputType.Keyboard then    if input.KeyCode == Enum.KeyCode.A then      print("A key was pressed!")      local character = script.Parent      local humanoid = character:FindFirstChild("Humanoid")      if humanoid then        humanoid:ChangeState(Enum.HumanoidStateType.Jumping)      end    end  endendgame:GetService("UserInputService").InputBegan:Connect(onInput)위 코드를 메월 게임에 추가하면, 캐릭터가 A 키 입력 시 점프하는 효과를 볼 수 있습니다.
Label: g

Text: As Sarah traveled back to the human world, she couldn't help but feel a sense of longing for the Shadow World. She had grown to love the magic and wonder of that place, and it was hard for her to imagine going back to a world without it. But she knew that she had a mission to fulfill, and that her destiny was entwined with both worlds.When she finally returned to the human world, Sarah found that it had changed. She had been gone for what felt like years, and the world had moved on without her. Her family and friends were shocked to see her, and they had a lot of questions. But Sarah was determined to keep her promise, and she began to use her knowledge and skills to help those in need.Sarah quickly realized that the human world was in danger, just like the Shadow World had been. There were dark forces at work, and people were suffering. Sarah knew that she had to act fast, and she began to use her magical powers to help those in need. She found that her powers were more powerful than ever, and she was able to do things that no human could do.Sarah's friends soon joined her in her quest, and together they set off on a journey to make the human world a better place. They faced many challenges and obstacles, but with their combined powers and skills, they were able to overcome them. They traveled the world, fighting against evil and injustice, and they were soon known as the protectors of the human world.As Sarah and her friends continued their journey, they realized that they had a purpose, and that they were meant to be together. They knew that they would always be a team, and that they would always be there for each other. They had found their true selves, and they had found their place in the world.The story concludes with a sense of hope and a new beginning, as Sarah and her friends continue their journey to make the world a better place, defending the human world and the Shadow World, and finding a new purpose and destiny.

Text: The Stoics and the Epicureans were two philosophical schools that emerged in ancient Greece and Rome. While both schools were concerned with the pursuit of happiness and the good life, they had different ideas about what constituted happiness and how it should be achieved.The Epicureans, who were followers of the philosopher Epicurus, believed that the key to happiness was the pursuit of pleasure, specifically the absence of physical pain and mental distress. They believed that individuals should focus on their own well-being and avoid getting involved in politics or other external affairs, and that the best way to achieve happiness was to live a simple and self-sufficient life.In contrast, the Stoics, who were followers of the philosopher Zeno, believed that the key to happiness was the pursuit of virtue and living in accordance with reason and nature. They believed that individuals should strive to cultivate the virtues of wisdom, justice, courage, and moderation, and that living in accordance with these virtues was essential to achieving happiness and fulfillment. They also believed that individuals should be indifferent to external events that were beyond their control, and that the best way to achieve happiness was to focus on one's own thoughts and actions, rather than trying to control external events.

Text:
以下是完整的 content.js 代码：javascriptCopy code(function () { const archiveTab = `
  • Archive
    • `; const navList = document.querySelector('.nav-list'); navList.insertAdjacentHTML('beforeend', archiveTab); const archiveLink = document.getElementById('archive-link'); const loadMDFile = async () => { const response = await fetch('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/qcrao/xargin-blog-crawler/main/xargin_blogs.md'); const mdText = await response.text(); return mdText; }; const convertMDToHTML = (mdText) => { const converter = new showdown.Converter(); const html = converter.makeHtml(mdText); return html; }; const createArchiveContent = (htmlContent) => { const archiveContainer = document.createElement('div'); archiveContainer.style.display = 'none'; archiveContainer.id = 'archive-content'; archiveContainer.innerHTML = htmlContent; return archiveContainer; }; const showArchive = () => { const mainContent = document.querySelector('.site-main'); mainContent.style.display = 'none'; const archiveContent = document.querySelector('#archive-content'); archiveContent.style.display = 'block'; }; const hideArchive = () => { const mainContent = document.querySelector('.site-main'); mainContent.style.display = 'block'; const archiveContent = document.querySelector('#archive-content'); archiveContent.style.display = 'none'; }; let isArchiveVisible = false; let isContentLoaded = false; archiveLink.addEventListener('click', async () => { if (!isContentLoaded) { const mdText = await loadMDFile(); const htmlContent = convertMDToHTML(mdText); const archiveContent = createArchiveContent(htmlContent); document.body.appendChild(archiveContent); isContentLoaded = true; } if (!isArchiveVisible) { showArchive(); isArchiveVisible = true; } else { hideArchive(); isArchiveVisible = false; } }); setInterval(async () => { const mdText = await loadMDFile(); const htmlContent = convertMDToHTML(mdText); const archiveContent = document.querySelector('#archive-content'); if (archiveContent) { archiveContent.innerHTML = htmlContent; } }, 3600000);})();在这个版本的代码中，loadMDFile 函数会从 GitHub 下载 xargin_blogs.md 文件，然后使用 convertMDToHTML 函数将 Markdown 转换为 HTML。每隔一小时，setInterval 函数会重新下载 MD 文件并转换为 HTML。

Text: 非常感谢您指出了这个问题。parse_list_item 函数需要根据不同情况来解析不同的内容。下面是修改后的代码：luaCopy codelocal json = require("json")local function parse_list_item(node, list_type)  local item_content = {}  if node.type == "m-list" then    local sublist = parse_list(node, list_type)    if sublist then      table.insert(item_content, sublist)    end  elseif node.type == "text" then    table.insert(item_content, pandoc.Str(node.text or ""))  end  if list_type == "bullet" then    return pandoc.BulletList(item_content)  elseif list_type == "number" then    return pandoc.OrderedList(item_content)  elseif list_type == "check" then    return pandoc.CheckList(item_content)  endendlocal function parse_list(node, list_type)  local children = node.children or {}  if #children == 0 then    return nil  end  local content = {}  for i, child in ipairs(children) do    if child.type == "m-listitem" then      local child_list_type = child.listType or list_type or "bullet"      table.insert(content, parse_list_item(child, child_list_type))    elseif child.type == "text" then      table.insert(content, pandoc.Str(child.text or ""))    end  end  if list_type == "bullet" then    return pandoc.BulletList(content)  elseif list_type == "number" then    return pandoc.OrderedList(content)  elseif list_type == "check" then    return pandoc.CheckList(content)  endendlocal function parse_json(json_str)  local json_obj = json.decode(json_str)  return parse_list(json_obj, "bullet")end在这个版本中，我们在 parse_list_item 中检查了 node 的 type，如果是 m-list 则解析其子元素。同时，我们在 parse_list 中，对 m-listitem 的子元素使用 parse_list_item 解析，并将其添加到 content 中。
