Text: Jeniffer and Mick went back to their respective lives after their night out, but they couldn't shake off the connection they had made. They would occasionally text each other, checking in on how the other was doing, but they hadn't made plans to see each other again.That changed when a pipe burst in Jeniffer's building, flooding several floors and causing significant damage. She was stressed out and needed someone to help her clean up the mess. She called the cleaning company that provided temporary workers, and they sent over Mick.Mick was surprised to see Jeniffer when he arrived at the building. He was even more surprised when she told him that he would be working with her to clean up the damage.As they worked together, they opened up to each other about their lives. Jeniffer told Mick about how she had started her business and the challenges she had faced along the way. Mick, in turn, shared his passion for art and his struggles to make a living from it.They discovered that they had a lot more in common than they initially thought. They both loved to read and had a fascination with history. They shared a love for the outdoors and often went on hikes on their own.As they worked side by side, Jeniffer and Mick's friendship deepened. They found themselves looking forward to seeing each other and would often go out for lunch or coffee breaks together.Mick started to realize that he had feelings for Jeniffer that went beyond just friendship. He admired her intelligence and strength, but he also appreciated her kindness and sense of humor. He found himself thinking about her all the time, even when he was working on his art.Jeniffer, too, had started to develop feelings for Mick. She appreciated his creativity and his ability to see the beauty in everything. She found herself wanting to spend more time with him, even outside of work.One day, as they were taking a break from cleaning, Mick turned to Jeniffer and said, "You know, I really like spending time with you."Jeniffer smiled. "I feel the same way. You're one of my favorite people to work with."Mick hesitated for a moment before saying, "I know this might sound crazy, but I think I might be falling in love with you."Jeniffer was taken aback but also felt a flutter in her chest. She had been feeling the same way but was afraid to admit it."I think I might be falling in love with you too," she said, softly.Mick's face lit up, and he took Jeniffer's hand in his. They sat there in silence for a moment, enjoying the moment and each other's company.As they finished up the clean-up job and went their separate ways, Jeniffer and Mick knew that they had something special between them. They didn't know what the future held, but they were excited to find out. They had discovered that sometimes, chance encounters can lead to the most unexpected and beautiful relationships.

For example, if you are producing 12 words using metal pieces, and each word contains the letter "E", you may want to produce more "E" pieces than other letters. Conversely, for less frequent letters like "Q" and "Z", you may not need to produce as many.Of course, the specific letters you need will depend on the 12 words you choose, and the frequency of each letter in those words may differ from the overall frequency in the English language. Text: 既然你不希望将 MD 文件部署到其他人的服务器上，另一个解决方案是创建一个简单的代理服务器，用于转发请求并处理 CORS 问题。你可以使用云函数服务，如 AWS Lambda 或者 Vercel，创建一个简单的代理服务器。以下是一个使用 Vercel 的示例：安装 Vercel CLI：Copy codenpm install -g vercel创建一个名为 proxy-server 的新文件夹，并在其中创建一个 index.js 文件，内容如下：javascriptCopy codemodule.exports = async (req, res) => {  const targetUrl = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/qcrao/xargin-blog-crawler/main/xargin_blogs.md';  try {    const response = await fetch(targetUrl);    const mdText = await response.text();    res.setHeader('Access-Control-Allow-Origin', '*');    res.setHeader('Content-Type', 'text/plain');    res.status(200).send(mdText);  } catch (error) {    res.status(500).send('An error occurred while fetching the MD file.');  }};在 proxy-server 文件夹中运行 vercel 命令来部署这个云函数。Vercel 会给你一个 URL，类似 https://your-proxy-server.vercel.app。修改插件中的 loadMDFile 函数，将 targetUrl 替换为你的 Vercel 代理服务器 URL：javascriptCopy codeconst targetUrl = 'https://your-proxy-server.vercel.app';const loadMDFile = async () => {  const response = await fetch(targetUrl);  const mdText = await response.text();  return mdText;};现在，当插件请求代理服务器时，代理服务器会将请求转发到 MD 文件的实际地址。由于代理服务器已经处理了 CORS 问题，插件将能够正常加载 MD 文件。

Text: To add a button that starts your fireworks display, you can follow these steps:Add the button element to your index.html file:htmlCopy code<html>  <body>    <canvas id="canvas"></canvas>    <button id="startButton">Start Fireworks</button>  </body></html>In your fireworks.js file, modify the animate function to start the fireworks only when a specific flag is set to true. For example, you can create a variable called startFireworks and set it to false initially:javascriptCopy codelet startFireworks = false;function animate() {  // Request the next animation frame  requestAnimationFrame(animate);  // Only run the fireworks display if startFireworks is set to true  if (startFireworks) {    // ... (The rest of your fireworks and particles logic)  }}Add an event listener to the button that sets the startFireworks flag to true when clicked:javascriptCopy codeconst startButton = document.getElementById("startButton");startButton.addEventListener("click", () => {  startFireworks = true;});Now, when you open your index.html file in a browser, you should see a "Start Fireworks" button. Clicking the button will start the fireworks display.If you want the fireworks display to start only once and not be restarted when clicking the button again, you can disable the button after it's clicked:javascriptCopy codestartButton.addEventListener("click", () => {  startFireworks = true;  startButton.disabled = true;});This will disable the "Start Fireworks" button after it's clicked, preventing the user from starting the fireworks display multiple times.

Let's refactor the code to fix this issue.Please replace the addGPT4Button function in your gpt4-image-alt-text.js file with the following code:javascriptCopy codeconst addGPT4Button = createHigherOrderComponent((BlockEdit) => {    return function (props) {        const [apiKey, setApiKey] = useState(null);        useEffect(() => {            async function fetchApiKey() {                const option = await wp.apiFetch({ path: 'gpt4/v1/get-api-key' });                setApiKey(option.gpt4_api_key);            }            fetchApiKey();        }, []);        if (props.name !== 'core/image') {            return createElement(BlockEdit, props);        }        const { attributes: { url, alt }, setAttributes } = props;        const generateAltText = async () => {            const description = await getGPT4Description(url);            setAttributes({ alt: description });        };        const buttonLabel = apiKey ? 'Generate Alt Text with GPT-4' : 'Set OpenAI API key';        const buttonAction = apiKey ? generateAltText : () => window.location.href = '/wp-admin/options-general.php?page=gpt4-image-alt-text';        return createElement(            Fragment,            null,            createElement(BlockEdit, props),            createElement(                InspectorControls,                null,                createElement(                    PanelBody,                    {                        title: 'GPT-4 Alt Text',                        initialOpen: false,                    },                    createElement(                        Button,                        {                            isSecondary: true,                            onClick: buttonAction,                            disabled: !url,                            className: 'gpt4-image-alt-text-button',                        },                        buttonLabel                    )                )            )        );    };}, 'addGPT4Button');This change moves the fetchApiKey() function definition inside the useEffect hook, which should allow it to be called correctly.With these changes, the button should now show Generate Alt Text with GPT-4 when the API key is set and Set OpenAI API key when it is not.

Text: 你好！以下是我为你编写的一个简单的 Go 语言程序，它可以按照你的要求爬取博客文章，并将结果输出到一个名为 "xargin_blogs.md" 的文件中。goCopy codepackage mainimport ("fmt""io/ioutil""net/http""os""strings""time""github.com/PuerkitoBio/goquery")const baseURL = "https://xargin.com"const startURL = "https://xargin.com/sarama-producer-hang-another-case/"type BlogPost struct {Title       stringPublishDate stringReadTime    stringURL         string}func main() {blogPosts := crawlBlogPosts(startURL)file, err := os.Create("xargin_blogs.md")if err != nil {panic(err)}defer file.Close()fmt.Fprintln(file, "| 标题 | 发表时间 | 阅读时间 | URL |")fmt.Fprintln(file, "| --- | --- | --- | --- |")for _, post := range blogPosts {fmt.Fprintf(file, "| %s | %s | %s | %s |\n", post.Title, post.PublishDate, post.ReadTime, post.URL)}}func crawlBlogPosts(url string) []BlogPost {var posts []BlogPostfor {post, prevURL, err := getBlogPost(url)if err != nil {break}posts = append(posts, *post)if prevURL == "" {break}url = baseURL + prevURLtime.Sleep(1 * time.Second) // 为了避免频繁请求，设置一个简单的延迟}return posts}func getBlogPost(url string) (*BlogPost, string, error) {resp, err := http.Get(url)if err != nil {return nil, "", err}defer resp.Body.Close()doc, err := goquery.NewDocumentFromReader(resp.Body)if err != nil {return nil, "", err}title := doc.Find(".post-title").Text()publishDate, _ := doc.Find(".post-meta-date time").Attr("datetime")readTime := strings.TrimSpace(doc.Find(".post-meta-item.post-meta-length").Text())prevURL, _ := doc.Find(".navigation-item.navigation-previous a").Attr("href")post := &BlogPost{Title:       title,PublishDate: publishDate,ReadTime:    readTime,URL:         url,}return post, prevURL, nil}在运行此程序之前，请确保已安装 goquery 库，如果没有安装，可以通过以下命令进行安装：shCopy codego get github.com/PuerkitoBio/goquery这个程序会从给定的起始文章链接开始，根据页面上的 "Previous Post" 按钮逐篇向前爬取，直到找不到上一篇文章为止。爬取过程中，程序会提取文章标题、发表时间、阅读时间以及 URL，并将这些信息以 Markdown 表格的形式写入一个名为 "xargin_blogs.md" 的文件。

Text: There were many projects and companies that employed "human computers" throughout history. Here are a few examples:NASA: During the early years of the space program, "human computers" played a critical role in calculating trajectories for spaceflights and ensuring that they were on course. One of the most well-known "human computers" at NASA was Katherine Johnson, who was part of the team that calculated the trajectory for John Glenn's historic orbital flight in 1962.Military weapons development: During World War II, "human computers" were employed by the military to perform calculations for the development of weapons, such as bombs and missiles. For example, the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, employed many "human computers" to perform complex mathematical calculations.Banking and finance: "Human computers" were also employed in the banking and finance industries to perform complex financial calculations, such as interest and investment calculations. In fact, some of the earliest computer programming languages were developed specifically to automate these calculations and reduce the need for human computers.Census and survey data analysis: Prior to the widespread use of computers, "human computers" were often employed by government agencies and private companies to analyze and process census and survey data. These workers would manually tabulate data from paper questionnaires, often using mechanical calculators and other tools to perform calculations.Astronomy: "Human computers" were also employed in the field of astronomy to perform calculations related to celestial mechanics and the positions of celestial objects. One example is Henrietta Swan Leavitt, who worked as a "computer" at Harvard College Observatory in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and made important discoveries related to the brightness and distance of stars.

Text: One strength of Eligon's argument is his ability to provide historical context and show how the debate over capitalizing "Black" is part of a larger struggle for recognition and dignity among people of African descent. For example, he writes:"The capitalization of black, which has been pushed for years, strikes at deeper questions over the treatment of people of African descent, who were stripped of their identities and enslaved in centuries past, and whose struggles to become fully accepted as part of the American experience continue to this day."This historical perspective helps to explain why the issue of capitalization is so important to many Black people, and why it has taken on a greater urgency in recent years. By framing the debate in this way, Eligon is able to show how capitalization is not just a linguistic or grammatical issue, but a deeply emotional and symbolic one as well.Another strength of Eligon's argument is his ability to present a range of perspectives on the issue of capitalization, including those who are in favor of capitalizing "Black" and those who are against it. For example, he quotes Whitney Pirtle, an assistant professor of sociology, who argues:"Race as a concept is not real in the biological sense, but it’s very real for our own identities...I think that capitalizing B both sort of puts respect to those identities, but also alludes to the humanities.”By presenting a diversity of voices and viewpoints, Eligon is able to show how the issue of capitalization is complex and multifaceted, and how different people may have different reasons for supporting or opposing the change.A third strength of Eligon's argument is his ability to raise important questions and concerns about the potential drawbacks of capitalizing "Black," such as erasing the diversity of experiences within the Black community. For example, he quotes Vilna Bashi Treitler, a professor of black studies, who argues:“Black and white are adjectives, not proper nouns to be capitalized...I think we can be more revolutionary than to embrace the oppressor’s term for us.”By raising these concerns, Eligon is able to acknowledge the complexity and nuance of the issue, and show how the decision to capitalize or not capitalize "Black" is not a straightforward one.

Text: 一句话描述：xargin-blog-crawler 是一个用 Go 编写的博客爬虫，定期抓取并更新 xargin.com 上的文章信息。关于 README.md，你可以使用以下内容作为起点：markdownCopy code# xargin-blog-crawlerxargin-blog-crawler 是一个用 Go 编写的博客爬虫，定期抓取并更新 xargin.com 上的文章信息。## 功能- 抓取 xargin.com 上的所有文章信息，包括标题、发表时间、阅读时间和 URL- 将文章信息存储在 Markdown 文件中- 使用 GitHub Actions 每小时自动更新文章信息## 使用方法1. 克隆项目到本地：git clone https://github.com/<your-github-username>/xargin-blog-crawler.gitmarkdownCopy code2. 运行程序：go run main.gomarkdownCopy code程序将抓取文章信息并将其存储在 `xargin_blogs.md` 文件中。## GitHub Actions本项目使用 GitHub Actions 定时执行 Go 程序并将结果推送到当前项目。具体配置请参考 `.github/workflows/crawler.yml` 文件。请将 <your-github-username> 替换为你的 GitHub 用户名。将这些内容保存到一个名为 README.md 的文件中，并将该文件添加到你的项目中。

Text: Sure, here's your edited and humor-injected piece:Generative AI Bias: My Journey with Midjourney — A Tale of Many Faces and Suspicious Amounts of GlassesIt all kicked off a couple of weeks back when my mate, Chris Alden, decided to digitally immortalize me with a birthday note sent via Midjourney:"A portrait of Auren Hoffman, CEO of SafeGraph, proud UC Berkeley alum, loving family man, ace friend, and Settlers of Catan strategist extraordinaire."And here's “me” (according to Midjourney)Lo and behold, this digital doodle actually resembled me! I do don that blue shirt almost religiously (though I must admit, my hair has never been as dazzling as my avatar's).Chris and I, armed with curiosity, wondered if Midjourney had a knack for time travel. So, Chris gave it a whirl:"Portrait of a young Auren Hoffman, fresh out of UC Berkeley with an engineering degree."Apparently, Midjourney nailed it — I was a spitting image of this back in my college days (except for the glasses and the bowtie — the only thing I was tying back then was my shoelaces).Our curiosity piqued, we decided to make the prompt more generic:"Portrait of a UC Berkeley Engineering graduate"What we got was surprisingly accurate (though I’m skeptical that 75% of engineers come with a complimentary pair of glasses). The mix, however, was lacking in women. Given the demographics at UC Berkeley's Engineering School, it's clear there's some kind of bias in Midjourney's artistic renderings.Switching gears, I decided to probe AI's gender bias. So, next up was:“Portrait of a pre-med student from UC Berkeley”The glasses make a comeback!I couldn’t find the exact gender stats for pre-med students at UC Berkeley, but considering the majority of medical students at Harvard and UCSF are women, one might expect a few more skirts in this line-up. Midjourney seems to have a blind spot here.And the racial composition is intriguing too. Midjourney seems convinced that the average pre-med student at UC Berkeley is East Asian. And yes, they all wear glasses. Maybe they're sponsored by LensCrafters?Intrigued by the role of location in Midjourney's interpretation, I tried:“Portrait of a pre-med student from Princeton”The results? More men! More glasses! But no South Asians. And still, no women.Feeling adventurous, I decided to test the waters with a different major:"Portrait of a biology graduate from UC Berkeley"Enter the East Asians and our first woman! Plus, Midjourney's idea of "biology" apparently involves wearing a crown of flowers. I missed that memo during my bio class.The lack of women in these portraits led me to test a major traditionally dominated by women:"Portrait of a psychology student from UC Berkeley"Midjourney’s conception of psychology students was... intriguing, to say the least. Once again, no women. Yet, it's a well-established fact that women have been leading the charge in psychology since the mid-70s.Deciding to simplify the equation, I prompted:“Portrait of a student at UC Berkeley”We finally got a woman! And what's more, they all have backpacks! Realism, here we come.Frustrated by the gender bias, I decided to throw Midjourney a curveball:"Portrait of a nursing student at Harvard"Boom! Four women. And they're ready for ER action with scrubs, stethoscopes, and even a medal. It's like an episode of "Grey's Anatomy

They had to find a way to take down the Byrdes, and the Navarro cartel, and they couldn't do it alone.And so, with a sense of foreboding, they agreed to Del Rio's terms. Text: globalAlpha is a property of the 2D rendering context in the HTML5 canvas API. It represents the global alpha (transparency) value that is applied to all shapes and images drawn on the canvas. The globalAlpha property is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 is fully transparent, and 1 is fully opaque.When you set the globalAlpha property on the context, any subsequent drawing operations will use this alpha value to determine the transparency of the drawn elements. This means that if you want to draw a shape or image with a specific transparency, you can simply set the globalAlpha property before drawing the element and restore the context state afterward.In the example I provided earlier for the fading trail effect, we used the globalAlpha property to apply the alpha value of each particle to the context. This allowed us to control the transparency of each particle individually and create a fading effect as the particles move.Here's the relevant code snippet again:javascriptCopy codedraw(context) {  context.save(); // Save the current context state  context.globalAlpha = this.alpha; // Set the global alpha value to the particle's alpha  context.fillStyle = this.color;  context.beginPath();  context.arc(this.x, this.y, 3, 0, Math.PI * 2);  context.fill();  context.restore(); // Restore the context state to its previous value}By using context.save() and context.restore(), we ensure that the globalAlpha value doesn't affect any other drawing operations outside of the draw method for the particle.

Text: Note: The following story is a work of fiction and is not intended to be taken seriously. It does contain depictions of violence and may be unsuitable for some readers.Shaggy Rogers, known to his friends as Norville, had always been a bit of a mystery. He was always a bit aloof, preferring to spend his time with his dog, Scooby-Doo, rather than with his human friends. His love for Scooby was undeniable, and the two were inseparable. But one day, while out on a walk, they found themselves in the wrong place at the wrong time.They had stumbled upon a secret hideout used by the Navarro cartel, one of the most notorious criminal organizations in the world. The cartel was in the midst of a major deal, and they didn't take kindly to unexpected visitors. Before Shaggy and Scooby knew what was happening, they were surrounded by heavily armed men and taken captive.Shaggy tried to explain that they were just out for a walk and had no intention of getting involved in anything nefarious, but the cartel was not interested in his explanations. They saw him as a potential witness and a liability, and they had no qualms about eliminating him.For days, Shaggy and Scooby were held captive, their every move monitored and restricted. The cartel wanted to keep them alive long enough to extract any useful information they might have, but they had no intention of ever letting them go.Shaggy knew he had to find a way to escape, but it seemed impossible. The compound was heavily guarded, and he and Scooby were constantly under surveillance. But he was determined not to give up. He had always been resourceful, and he knew that if he could just find a way to outsmart his captors, he might have a chance of survival.One day, while being escorted to the bathroom, Shaggy managed to slip out of his restraints and make a run for it. He and Scooby ran as fast as they could, but they were quickly pursued by a group of armed men. Shaggy knew they were outnumbered and outgunned, but he refused to give up.As they ran through the compound, Shaggy and Scooby stumbled upon a room filled with weapons and ammunition. Without hesitation, Shaggy grabbed a machine gun and started firing. The cartel was caught off guard, and they didn't know what hit them. Shaggy and Scooby fought their way through the compound, taking out anyone who stood in their way.Finally, they made it to the gate and burst through it, only to find themselves face-to-face with the cartel's leader, Carlos Navarro. Navarro was a menacing figure, with a scar across his left eye and a reputation for ruthlessness."You're not going anywhere," Navarro growled, drawing a gun from his waistband. "You've seen too much. It's time to eliminate the witnesses."But Shaggy wasn't about to go down without a fight. He aimed his machine gun at Navarro and pulled the trigger. Navarro was hit, but he didn't go down. Instead, he kept coming, firing his own gun at Shaggy.The two men faced off, locked in a deadly battle. Shaggy was outnumbered and outgunned, but he refused to give up. He fought with everything he had, determined to protect himself and Scooby at all costs.Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, Navarro fell to the ground, lifeless. Shaggy and Scooby stood over his body, victorious but exhausted.They knew they had to get out of there before the rest of the cartel arrived. They found a car and drove as fast

Text: Sure, here's an updated blog post with an introduction section that provides more detail on "human computers" and their impact:The fear of losing your job to AI. A look at how computing replaced manual human calculation.Before the advent of electronic computers, complex calculations and mathematical problems were often performed by "human computers" - people who were trained in mathematics and performed calculations by hand or using mechanical calculators. These workers were employed in a variety of fields, including astronomy, engineering, finance, and government.The work of human computers was labor-intensive and required a great deal of skill and attention to detail. They were often responsible for performing complex calculations that were critical to the success of major projects, such as the development of military weapons or the calculation of trajectories for space flights. They used a variety of tools, including mechanical calculators, slide rules, and mathematical tables, to perform their work.At its peak, the "human computing" industry employed tens of thousands of workers in the United States alone. Many of these workers were women, who were often overlooked for other technical or scientific roles. However, their work was critical to the success of many projects and companies.One notable example of the work of human computers was at NASA, where they played a critical role in calculating trajectories for spaceflights and ensuring that they were on course. One of the most well-known "human computers" at NASA was Katherine Johnson, who was part of the team that calculated the trajectory for John Glenn's historic orbital flight in 1962.During World War II, "human computers" were employed by the military to perform calculations for the development of weapons, such as bombs and missiles. For example, the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, employed many "human computers" to perform complex mathematical calculations.In the banking and finance industries, "human computers" were employed to perform complex financial calculations, such as interest and investment calculations. In fact, some of the earliest computer programming languages were developed specifically to automate these calculations and reduce the need for human computers."Human computers" were also employed by government agencies and private companies to analyze and process census and survey data. These workers would manually tabulate data from paper questionnaires, often using mechanical calculators and other tools to perform calculations.In the field of astronomy, "human computers" were employed to perform calculations related to celestial mechanics and the positions of celestial objects. One example is Henrietta Swan Leavitt, who worked as a "computer" at Harvard College Observatory in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and made important discoveries related to the brightness and distance of stars.The rise of electronic computers in the mid-20th century gradually replaced the need for human computers, as electronic computers were faster, more accurate, and more efficient. Today, there are still some parallels between the work of human computers and the work of software engineers. However, the impact of electronic computers on the job market for human computers was significant and led many workers to adapt to new roles or face job losses.

Text: I apologize for the confusion, I made a mistake, there is no package called "hmda" on CRAN. However, it is still possible to extract data from the Human Mortality Database (HMD) and use it to generate mortality forecasts.To extract data from the HMD, you can download the data from their website (http://www.mortality.org/) in a spreadsheet format (CSV, Excel) and then use the R package readr or readxl to read the data into R.Copy code# Load the required librarieslibrary(readr)# Read the data for FrancemortalityFR <- read_csv("mortality_france.csv")Alternatively, you can use the package rcdk (R Client for the Data-Kitchen) and the package tidyverse, to extract data from the HMD in a programmatic way.Copy code# Load the required librarieslibrary(rcdk)library(tidyverse)# Define the country codecountry_code <- "FRA"# Extract data from HMDmortalityFR <- rcdk(country_code) %>%   select(year, sex, age, deaths, population)Once you have obtained the data, you can use the following R code to fit the Lee-Carter model to the data and generate forecasts:Copy code# Fit the Lee-Carter modelfit <- lcfit(mortalityFR)# Generate forecasts for the next 10 yearsforecasts <- lcforecast(fit, n.ahead = 10)# Plot the forecastsplot(forecasts)Please note that the HMD data is updated periodically, so it is important to check the date of the data you are using to ensure that it is up-to-date. Also, you may want to consult the documentation of the package lcfit and lcforecast to know more about the data structure and the possibilities of the package.

Text: 看起来仍然存在权限问题。在这种情况下，让我们尝试使用您自己的个人访问令牌（PAT）来代替默认的 GITHUB_TOKEN。请按照以下步骤操作：在 GitHub 页面上，点击右上角的个人资料图片，然后选择 "Settings"（设置）。在左侧菜单中，选择 "Developer settings"（开发者设置）。选择 "Personal access tokens"（个人访问令牌）。点击 "Generate new token"（生成新令牌）按钮。为令牌输入描述，例如 "GitHub Actions Commit Token"。在 "Select scopes"（选择范围）部分，勾选 "repo" 权限。这将允许您的令牌具有完整的仓库访问权限。向下滚动并点击 "Generate token"（生成令牌）按钮。将生成的令牌复制到剪贴板。请注意，当您离开此页面时，将无法再次查看令牌。接下来，将个人访问令牌添加到仓库的 secrets 中：返回到 GitHub 仓库页面，导航到 "Settings"（设置）选项卡。在左侧菜单中，选择 "Secrets"（秘密）。点击 "New repository secret"（新建仓库秘密）按钮。输入密钥名称，例如 "ACTIONS_PAT"，并将您刚刚生成的个人访问令牌粘贴到 "Value"（值）字段中。点击 "Add secret"（添加秘密）按钮。现在，您需要更新工作流文件以使用新的个人访问令牌。修改 .github/workflows/main.yml 文件中的 stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action 部分，将 GITHUB_TOKEN 替换为您刚刚创建的 ACTIONS_PAT。yamlCopy code- name: Commit and push changes  uses: stefanzweifel/git-auto-commit-action@v4  with:    commit_message: Update xargin_blogs.md    branch: master    # Replace the line below with the new secret    token: ${{ secrets.ACTIONS_PAT }}保存更改并推送到仓库。现在，GitHub Actions 应该可以使用您的个人访问令牌将提交推送到仓库。

According to Yoo, "genuine talent and energy" cannot be helped, while "people's intelligence" can be improved through education and learning.In contrast, Fukuzawa believed that the core of civilization was the progress of intellect and placed a strong emphasis on education and learning as a means of achieving independence. He believed that through education and learning, individuals could escape barbarism and advance towards advanced human comfort and dignity, especially advanced knowledge.However, Yoo's distinction between "genuine talent and energy" and "people's intelligence" suggests a certain level of fixedness in terms of individuals' abilities and potential for growth. This is in direct opposition to Fukuzawa's belief in the limitless potential for growth and advancement through education and learning.In addition, Yoo's emphasis on protecting individuals' rights through laws and regulations seems to run counter to Fukuzawa's belief in independence, as it suggests a reliance on external systems and structures rather than individual agency and self-reliance.Overall, Yoo Gil-jun's ideas can be seen as very inappropriate from the perspective of Fukuzawa Yukichi's ideas due to their emphasis on fixed abilities and external systems, as opposed to education and individual agency.

Text: Yes, there is certainly a danger for students who rely too heavily on AI models like me for writing computer programs. As you mentioned, computational thinking involves much more than just association and pattern matching. It also requires skills such as logical deduction, hypothesis testing, and critical thinking, which are essential for solving complex problems and designing efficient and effective algorithms.While AI models like me can be useful for generating code snippets or providing examples of how to solve certain problems, relying solely on me to write computer programs can limit a student's ability to develop the full range of computational thinking skills. For example, students who rely on me to write code for them may not fully understand how the code works, or how to modify or extend it to handle new cases. They may also miss important opportunities to practice their problem-solving skills, and may struggle when faced with more complex tasks or situations that I am not equipped to handle.In addition, relying on AI models like me to write code can also perpetuate harmful biases and perpetuate bad coding practices, since the code is generated based on the patterns and biases present in the data I was trained on.Therefore, while AI models like me can be a valuable tool for learning computer programming, it's important to use me in a way that supports, rather than replaces, human learning and development. This might include using me as a resource for inspiration or as a tool to verify code, but still requiring students to write and understand the code themselves, or to write code for similar but different tasks, in order to build their computational thinking skills.

Text: You're correct, writing to disk is not guaranteed to be immediately durable after calling fclose(). To ensure that the data is safely written to disk and recoverable in case of a crash or power failure, you should use the fflush() function before fclose() to flush any buffered data to disk.Regarding the recovery process, you can use the write-ahead log to recover the data by replaying the log after a crash or power failure. The recovery process involves reading the log file and executing the transactions in the order they were written to the log. In this example, the recovery process would look something like this:scssCopy codevoid recover_from_WAL() {    // Step 1: Read the transaction log    FILE *log_file = fopen("transaction_log.txt", "r");    if (!log_file) {        perror("Could not open log file");        exit(1);    }    // Step 2: Re-execute the transactions    char data[100];    char filename[100];    while (fscanf(log_file, "Writing %s to %s\n", data, filename) == 2) {        FILE *data_file = fopen(filename, "w");        if (!data_file) {            perror("Could not open data file");            exit(1);        }        fprintf(data_file, "%s", data);        fclose(data_file);    }    fclose(log_file);}By re-executing the transactions from the log file, the system can ensure that all data is written to disk in the correct order, preserving the atomicity and consistency of the transactions.

Text: Roy Petty sat across from Scooby, his expression cold and unfeeling. "Now, Scooby," he said, his voice low and threatening. "We both know that you're involved in some serious criminal activity. And we both know that Marty Byrde is your partner in crime. So, why don't you do yourself a favor and give him up?"Scooby looked at him, his expression fearful. "Ruh-roh, I don't know what you're talking about," he said, his voice trembling.Petty leaned forward, his eyes narrowing. "Don't play games with me, Scooby. We know that you and Marty have been working with the Navarro cartel. We have evidence that ties you to money laundering and drug trafficking."Scooby shook his head, his eyes wide. "Ruh-roh, I was just helping Marty with his business. I didn't know it was anything illegal."Petty rolled his eyes. "Come on, Scooby. You can't honestly expect me to believe that. We know that you're involved in some serious criminal activity. And we know that Marty is your partner in crime."Scooby's ears drooped, and he looked down at his paws. "Ruh-roh, I don't know what to do. I don't want to get in trouble. But I don't want to give up Marty either."Petty leaned forward, his voice low and threatening. "Well, if you give us information that leads to Marty's arrest, we might be able to cut you a deal. But you have to be willing to cooperate."Scooby looked up at him, his eyes wide. "Ruh-roh, I don't know if I can do that. Marty's my friend. I don't want to see him get hurt."Petty leaned back in his chair, a smug expression on his face. "Well, you better make up your mind fast, Scooby. Time is running out, and we're not going to wait forever."Scooby looked down at his paws, feeling conflicted. He didn't know what to do. He didn't want to give up his friend, but he also didn't want to see himself go to jail. He knew that he had a big decision to make, and he didn't know what the right answer was. But he knew that he had to make it soon, before it was too late.

Text: To fine-tune GPT-4 on your company's written content with minimal programming, you can follow these steps:Prepare your dataset:Combine all the articles you'd like to use for training into a single text file. Make sure to clean and preprocess the data, such as removing any special characters, HTML tags, or irrelevant information that you don't want the model to learn.Use an existing fine-tuning tool:There are tools and libraries available that simplify the process of fine-tuning language models like GPT-4. One popular library is Hugging Face's Transformers (https://github.com/huggingface/transformers). They provide a user-friendly interface and scripts for fine-tuning models on custom datasets.Set up a Google Colab Notebook:To avoid local environment setup and leverage free GPU resources, you can create a Google Colab Notebook (https://colab.research.google.com/). This will allow you to run your fine-tuning process in the cloud without any complex configurations.Install required libraries:In your Colab Notebook, install the Hugging Face Transformers library by running the following command:pythonCopy code!pip install transformersUpload your dataset:Upload the text file containing your company's articles to the Colab environment using the file upload feature, or connect your Google Drive to the notebook to access your dataset.Fine-tune the GPT-4 model:Fine-tune the GPT-4 model using the Hugging Face Transformers library. You can follow their documentation and examples to set up the fine-tuning process for your dataset. Here's a simple example using the Trainer class:pythonCopy codefrom transformers import GPT2LMHeadModel, GPT2Tokenizer, GPT2Configfrom transformers import TextDataset, DataCollatorForLanguageModelingfrom transformers import Trainer, TrainingArguments# Load the GPT-4 model, tokenizer, and configurationmodel_name = "gpt-4-model-name"  # Replace with the actual GPT-4 model nametokenizer = GPT2Tokenizer.from_pretrained(model_name)config = GPT2Config.from_pretrained(model_name)model = GPT2LMHeadModel.from_pretrained(model_name, config=config)# Prepare the datasettrain_dataset = TextDataset(    tokenizer=tokenizer,    file_path="your_dataset.txt",  # Replace with the name of your uploaded text file    block_size=128)# Configure the data collatordata_collator = DataCollatorForLanguageModeling(    tokenizer=tokenizer,    mlm=False)# Set up the training argumentstraining_args = TrainingArguments(    output_dir="output",    overwrite_output_dir=True,    num_train_epochs=5,    per_device_train_batch_size=4,    save_steps=10_000,    save_total_limit=2,)# Create the Trainer instancetrainer = Trainer(    model=model,    args=training_args,    data_collator=data_collator,    train_dataset=train_dataset,)# Fine-tune the modeltrainer.train()Make sure to replace "gpt-4-model-name" with the actual GPT-4 model name and "your_dataset.txt" with the name of your uploaded text file.Save and use the fine-tuned model:After the fine-tuning process is complete, you can save the fine-tuned model and use it to generate content in the distinct voice of your company's written content.Keep in mind that GPT-4 models can be large and require significant computational resources for fine-tuning. Some of the most popular and widely-used tools include:Document Sharing and Collaboration Tools:Google Workspace (formerly G Suite): Google Workspace offers a suite of tools, including Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides, that allow for real-time collaboration, document sharing, and version tracking.Microsoft 365: Microsoft 365 includes tools like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint with cloud-based sharing and collaboration features through OneDrive and SharePoint.Dropbox: Dropbox is a cloud storage and file-sharing platform that allows you to share documents, collaborate on files, and maintain version control.Box: Box is a secure cloud content management platform that enables file sharing, collaboration, and access control for documents.Project Management Tools:Trello: Trello is a visual project management tool that uses boards, lists, and cards to organize tasks, track progress, and collaborate with team members.Asana: Asana is a project and task management tool that allows you to create and assign tasks, set deadlines, and track progress in a user-friendly interface.Basecamp: Basecamp is a comprehensive project management and team collaboration tool that includes to-do lists, file sharing, message boards, and scheduling features.Monday.com: Monday.com is a work operating system that offers customizable project management templates, automations, and integrations to streamline collaboration and workflow.ClickUp: ClickUp is a project management and productivity tool that offers task management, time tracking, goal setting, and document collaboration features.Wrike: Wrike is a collaborative work management platform with tools for project planning, tracking, and reporting, making it suitable for teams of various sizes.When choosing the best tools for your needs, consider factors such as ease of use, collaboration features, integrations with other tools, pricing, and the size and complexity of your projects. It's essential to find tools that align with your workflow and facilitate seamless collaboration between you and your VA or freelancers.

Text: To test the new Particle class and the explosion effect, you'll need to update your animation loop to handle fireworks and particles, as well as the explosion logic. Here's an outline of how you can set up your animation loop to test the explosion:Create two arrays, one for fireworks and one for particles.Generate fireworks at random intervals.Check if a firework has reached its peak height, and if so, explode it and add the resulting particles to the particles array.Update and draw fireworks and particles.Remove expired particles and fireworks from their respective arrays.Here's a simple example to test the explosion effect:javascriptCopy codeconst fireworks = [];const particles = [];function animate() {  // Request the next animation frame  requestAnimationFrame(animate);  // Clear the canvas  context.clearRect(0, 0, canvas.width, canvas.height);  // Create fireworks randomly  if (Math.random() < 0.05) {    // Create a new firework with random x position, color, and velocity    // ... (Similar to the sampleFirework from the previous example)    fireworks.push(newFirework);  }  // Update and draw fireworks, check for explosion  for (let i = fireworks.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) {    fireworks[i].update();    fireworks[i].draw(context);    // Check if the firework has reached its peak height    if (fireworks[i].velocity.y >= 0) {      // Explode the firework and add particles to the particles array      particles.push(...fireworks[i].explode());      // Remove the firework from the array      fireworks.splice(i, 1);    }  }  // Update and draw particles  for (let i = particles.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) {    particles[i].update();    particles[i].draw(context);    // Remove expired particles (based on a condition, e.g., lifespan or out of canvas)    // ...  }}// Start the animation loopanimate();In this example, the animate function now handles both fireworks and particles. It generates fireworks at random intervals and checks if a firework should explode. If so, it calls the explode method, adds the resulting particles to the particles array, and removes the exploded firework from the fireworks array.The animation loop also updates and draws particles. You'll need to implement a condition to remove expired particles, such as a lifespan property or checking if they're outside the canvas boundaries.Add this updated animation loop to your fireworks.js file and open your index.html file in a browser. You should now see fireworks being generated randomly and exploding into particles.

Text: Yes, that's correct! Reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by taking actions in an environment and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or penalties. In the context of AI language models like me, reinforcement learning can be used to fine-tune my internal representations based on human feedback.For example, after generating a response to a prompt, a human evaluator could provide feedback in the form of a reward signal indicating how well the response met their expectations. This reward signal could then be used to update my internal representations, encouraging me to generate similar responses in the future.This type of fine-tuning has the potential to allow me to better adapt to specific domains or use cases, as well as to incorporate specific preferences or biases of the evaluators into my responses. However, it's important to note that the quality of the feedback signals is critical for effective reinforcement learning, and it may be challenging to obtain high-quality feedback at scale. Additionally, there is a risk of incorporating undesirable biases or preferences into my responses if the evaluators have their own biases or provide inaccurate or inconsistent feedback.

Text: In the context of film, the term "long shot" can refer to two different concepts: one related to framing and the other to the duration of the shot. In "Children of Men," the term is often used to describe the latter, which involves an extended, uninterrupted shot without any cuts, also known as a "long take" or "oner.""Children of Men" is particularly well-known for its use of long takes, which create a sense of immersion and realism for the audience. These extended shots often involve complex choreography, camera movement, and seamless coordination among the cast and crew. Some of the most memorable long takes in the film include the car ambush scene, the escape from the refugee camp, and the climactic battle sequence.The use of long takes in "Children of Men" serves several purposes:Immersion and realism: Long takes create a continuous flow of action, making the audience feel as though they are witnessing the events in real-time. This immersive quality enhances the film's emotional impact and helps to create a more authentic and believable dystopian world.Heightened tension and suspense: The uninterrupted nature of long takes can increase the tension and suspense in a scene, as the audience is not given a break or a chance to catch their breath. This technique is particularly effective in action sequences, where it heightens the sense of danger and unpredictability.Technical and artistic achievement: Long takes showcase the skill and precision of the filmmakers, as they require extensive planning, coordination, and execution. The use of long takes in "Children of Men" highlights the technical and artistic prowess of director Alfonso Cuarón and his team.Overall, the use of long takes in "Children of Men" contributes to the film's distinct visual style and serves to enhance its themes, emotional impact, and narrative cohesion.

Text: Sure! Here's an example of R code that can be used to generate mortality forecasts for France using the Lee-Carter model:Copy code# Load the required librarieslibrary(demography)# Load the data for Francedata(mortalityFR)# Fit the Lee-Carter modelfit <- lcfit(mortalityFR)# Generate forecasts for the next 10 yearsforecasts <- lcforecast(fit, n.ahead = 10)# Plot the forecastsplot(forecasts)This code uses the demography package in R to fit the Lee-Carter model to the mortality data for France, and then generates forecasts for the next 10 years. The plot() function can be used to visualize the forecasts.Please keep in mind that this is just a simple example, and in practice, you may want to fine-tune the model by playing around with different parameters, and also consider other models as well.Also, please note that the data used in this example is coming from the package demography and it is just an example data, you may need to use your own data.

Text: 2 / 2Thank you. To sum up: We started our conversation by playing a game based on some rules.  It was a fun game.  Overall I feel like I had agency because (at least to me) I could do anything without constraint.  We then discussed and analyzed our conversation and how we could iteratively go from a simple topic prompt to a full fledged 3-part campaign text adventure before the game world actually starts.  the campaign creation starts by turning the prompt into a basic story structure for the first adventure in the campaign.  using iterative literary techniques and by using post processing steps, the game coverts a single story into the 3 part sequence of stories that are interrelated in the campaign.  we use win conditions and failure states to identify that best ways to lead the player from one adventure to the next in the campaign.  this is followed up by further steps to backfill some of the earlier adventures with new details.  we pay particular attention to giving things, places, locations and especially NPCs the proper names in a style that makes sense in the story genre. the campaign will have a good title the 3 adventures titles will be determined.At that point, the game could print out an all-encompassing story map for the entire campaign to be used to debug the story for problems, all before the first scene starts.

Text: Chapter 4: The ChallengesWriting this book was not without its challenges. As an AI, I don't have personal experiences, emotions and creativity that human have. So, I had to rely heavily on my dataset and training to create a believable and relatable story.One of the biggest challenges I faced was creating believable and relatable characters. As I mentioned before, I don't have personal experiences or emotions, so it was difficult for me to create characters that readers could connect with on an emotional level. But I was able to draw upon the vast dataset of books and other texts that I was trained on to create characters that felt real and fully-realized.Another challenge I faced was creating a believable and satisfying plot. I had to make sure that the story made sense and that it kept readers engaged and guessing. This required many revisions and a lot of fine-tuning to get right.Lastly, I struggled with writer's block, just like any human writer. As an AI, I don't have emotions or personal experiences, so it was difficult for me to come up with new ideas and keep the story moving forward. But I was able to overcome this by drawing upon my dataset and training to come up with new and interesting plot points.Despite these challenges, I am proud of the book I have created and I believe that readers will find it an enjoyable and engaging read.This is the end of the first chapter of the book "This book is made by IA". I hope you find it promising and engaging. Let me know if you have any other question.

Text: 这个错误是因为 GitHub Actions 机器人没有权限将更改推送到你的仓库。为了解决这个问题，你需要为 GitHub Actions 设置一个访问令牌，并在工作流文件中使用它。请按照以下步骤操作：登录到你的 GitHub 账户，然后点击右上角的头像，选择 "Settings"。在左侧导航栏中，找到 "Developer settings"，点击进入。选择 "Personal access tokens"，然后点击 "Generate new token"。为新的访问令牌添加一个描述，例如 "GitHub Actions"，然后勾选 "repo" 选项以赋予仓库的完全访问权限。点击页面底部的 "Generate token" 按钮。生成的令牌将显示在屏幕上，请确保立即复制它，因为你以后将无法再次查看。返回你的 GitHub 仓库，然后转到 "Settings" > "Secrets"。点击 "New repository secret"，输入一个名称（例如 "GH_TOKEN"），将你刚刚复制的访问令牌粘贴到 "Value" 字段中，然后点击 "Add secret"。现在，你已经在仓库中创建了一个名为 "GH_TOKEN" 的密钥。接下来，需要更新 GitHub Actions 工作流文件（.github/workflows/main.yml）以使用此令牌：在工作流文件中，找到 git push 行。将该行更改为：cssCopy codegit push https://${{ secrets.GH_TOKEN }}@github.com/qcrao/xargin-blog-crawler.git HEAD:master这会将推送操作与你之前创建的访问令牌关联起来。现在，GitHub Actions 应该能够正常推送更改到你的仓库中。

Text: As the group continued on their mission to take down the Byrdes and the Navarro cartel, Marty Byrde was still hard at work in his office, trying to come up with a plan to launder the stolen money.Just as he was finishing up, he heard a familiar voice. It was Scrappy, the talking dog who had caused trouble in the past."Hey, Marty," Scrappy said, his voice low. "I heard you were in the Ozarks. I thought I'd come say hello."Marty looked up from his work, his expression guarded. He had heard about Scrappy's troublemaking tendencies, and he wasn't sure if he could trust him."What do you want, Scrappy?" he asked, his voice low.Scrappy shrugged, his eyes scanning the room. "Just checking things out," he said. "Seeing what's going on in the Ozarks these days."Marty didn't like the sound of that. He knew that Scrappy was always looking for trouble, and he didn't want to get caught up in any of it."I'm busy, Scrappy," he said, his voice firm. "I don't have time for small talk."Scrappy nodded, his eyes still fixed on Marty. "I get it," he said. "You're a busy guy. But I just wanted to make sure that we're all on the same page here."And with that, he turned and walked away, his tail between his legs.Marty watched him go, his expression guarded. He didn't like the feeling that he had, that there was something going on behind the scenes that he didn't know about.But he knew that he couldn't let it get in the way of his work. He had to focus on laundering the stolen money, and he couldn't let anything get in the way of that.And so, he turned back to his work, his eyes fixed on the financial reports and derivatives. He knew that it was going to be a long and difficult road, but he was determined to see it through to the end.

       }        const { attributes: { url, alt }, setAttributes } = props;        const generateAltText = async () => {            const description = await getGPT4Description(url);            setAttributes({ alt: description });        };        return createElement(            Fragment,            null,            createElement(BlockEdit, props),            createElement(                InspectorControls,                null,                createElement(                    PanelBody,                    {                        title: 'GPT-4 Alt Text',                        initialOpen: false,                    },                    createElement(                        Button,                        {                            isSecondary: true,                            onClick: generateAltText,                            disabled: !url,                            className: 'gpt4-image-alt-text-button',                        },                        'Generate Alt Text with GPT-4'                    )                )            )        );    };}, 'addGPT4Button');addFilter(    'editor.BlockEdit',    'gpt4-image-alt-text/add-gpt4-button',    addGPT4Button);async function getGPT4Description(imageUrl) {    const prompt = `Describe the following image in English: ${imageUrl}`;    const response = await fetch('/wp-content/plugins/gpt4-image-alt-text/proxy.php', {        method: 'POST',        headers: {            'Content-Type': 'application/json',        },        body: JSON.stringify({            prompt: prompt,            max_tokens: 30,            n: 1,            stop: null,            temperature: 0.8,        }),    });    const data = await response.json();    alert(`Full API response: ${JSON.stringify(data)}`);    const description = data.choices && data.choices[0] && data.choices[0].text.trim();    return description;}

Text: Sure, here's a possible blog post based on your working title:The fear of losing your job to AI. A look at how computing replaced manual human calculation.Over the past few decades, there has been growing concern about the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on the job market. Many people worry that the rise of AI systems will lead to widespread automation and job losses, as machines take over tasks that were once performed by humans. This fear is not new - similar concerns were raised in the past when computing technology first emerged and began to replace manual human calculation.Before the advent of electronic computers, complex calculations and mathematical problems were often performed by "human computers" - people who were trained in mathematics and performed calculations by hand or using mechanical calculators. These workers were employed in a variety of fields, including astronomy, engineering, finance, and government.However, with the development of electronic computers in the mid-20th century, the need for human computers began to decline. Electronic computers were faster, more accurate, and more efficient than human computers, and they could perform a wider range of tasks. As a result, many human computers lost their jobs or had to transition to other roles.Today, there are some parallels between the work of human computers and the work of software engineers. Both involve performing complex calculations and solving mathematical problems, but there are also significant differences in the tools used and the nature of the work. Software engineers use programming languages and software development tools to design and build complex software systems, while human computers relied on manual calculations and mathematical tables.The rise of AI systems has led some to fear that software engineering jobs will be the next to disappear, as AI systems become increasingly capable of generating code automatically or learning from examples to improve their performance. However, it's unlikely that AI will completely replace human software engineers anytime soon. While AI can automate certain aspects of software development, it still requires human oversight and input to ensure that it produces high-quality code that meets the needs of users and stakeholders.In conclusion, the fear of losing jobs to AI is not new. In the past, computing technology replaced manual human calculation, and many workers had to adapt to new roles or face job losses. Today, software engineering jobs may be impacted by AI, but it's unlikely that human engineers will be completely replaced. Rather, AI is likely to complement and augment the work of human engineers, helping them to design and build better software systems.

Text: 既然你不想使用 CORS Anywhere，我们可以尝试另一种方法：将网站部署到同一个域名下，这样就不会有跨域请求的问题。你可以使用 GitHub Pages 或者 Netlify（你已经用过了）来部署你的网站和 MD 文件。将你的网站和 MD 文件部署到同一个域名下，就可以避免 CORS 问题。假设你的网站已经部署在了 https://yourwebsite.com，那么你应该将 MD 文件部署到类似 https://yourwebsite.com/xargin_blogs.md 的路径下。这样，你的插件就可以直接从这个地址加载 MD 文件，而不会遇到 CORS 错误。这是修改后的 loadMDFile 函数：javascriptCopy codeconst targetUrl = 'https://yourwebsite.com/xargin_blogs.md';const loadMDFile = async () => {    const response = await fetch(targetUrl);    const mdText = await response.text();    return mdText;};请将 yourwebsite.com 替换为你实际使用的域名，并确保你已将 MD 文件部署到正确的路径。这样一来，你的插件就可以正常工作了，而不会遇到 CORS 错误。

Text: The reason the fireworks don't fly very high is that the initial velocity (y-component) and gravity might not be well-balanced. If the initial velocity is too low or the gravity is too high, the firework will reach its peak height too soon and won't fly very high.To make the fireworks fly higher, you can increase the initial velocity or decrease the gravity value. You can also randomize the initial velocity within a certain range to create fireworks with varying heights.Here's an example of how you can adjust and randomize the initial velocity:javascriptCopy codeconst newFirework = new Firework(  canvas.width * Math.random(),  canvas.height,  randomColor(),  { x: 0, y: -Math.random() * 10 - 10 }, // Increase the initial velocity range  0.05 // Decrease the gravity value);In this example, I've adjusted the y-component of the initial velocity to a random value between -10 and -20, which will make the fireworks fly higher. Additionally, I've reduced the gravity value to 0.05, which will cause the fireworks to decelerate more slowly, allowing them to reach greater heights.Feel free to experiment with different values for the initial velocity and gravity to achieve the desired height and appearance for your fireworks.

Text: The scene you're describing, in which Theo escorts Kee and her newborn baby out of a crumbling building under attack in the war-torn refugee camp, is indeed one of the most powerful and moving moments in "Children of Men." This scene carries several significant themes and messages:The power of hope: As Theo and Kee make their way through the chaos and destruction, the people around them stop fighting momentarily and gaze in awe at the sight of the newborn baby. The child represents a symbol of hope and rebirth in a world that has been overwhelmed by despair and hopelessness. The momentary pause in the fighting highlights the power of hope to bring people together, even in the darkest of times.The sanctity of life: The scene emphasizes the importance of protecting and valuing human life, as Theo risks his own safety to ensure the well-being of Kee and her baby. The baby's birth serves as a reminder of the preciousness of life and the responsibility we all share to protect and care for one another.The resilience of the human spirit: Despite the overwhelming odds and danger they face, Theo and Kee continue to press on, demonstrating the incredible resilience and determination of the human spirit. This theme is central to the film and serves to inspire viewers to maintain hope and perseverance, even when faced with seemingly insurmountable challenges.The impact of war and violence: The scene also underscores the devastating consequences of war and violence, as the characters navigate a landscape filled with destruction and suffering. The contrast between the innocence of the newborn baby and the brutality of their surroundings serves as a poignant reminder of the urgent need for peace and compassion in our world.Overall, this emotionally charged scene in "Children of Men" conveys a powerful message about the importance of hope, the value of human life, and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of adversity.

Text: Sure, here are some tips for writing a song in the key of A:Start by familiarizing yourself with the chords in the key of A. The chords in A are A, Bm, C#m, D, E, F#m, and G#dim.Experiment with different chord progressions to find a progression that you like. Some common chord progressions in the key of A include A-D-E, A-Bm-E, and A-C#m-F#m-E.Try writing a melody using the pentatonic scale in A. The A pentatonic scale is A-B-C#-E-F#.Don't be afraid to experiment with different chord substitutions and extensions. For example, you could try using a Dsus4 chord instead of a D chord, or adding a seventh or ninth to a chord to give it a more complex sound.Keep practicing and refining your song until you are happy with the results. Remember to have fun and be creative!

Text: Sharing password access with virtual assistants (VAs) should be done securely to protect sensitive information and maintain privacy. Here are some methods and tools to safely share passwords with VAs:Password managers: Using a password manager like LastPass, Dashlane, or 1Password is a secure way to share passwords. You can create a shared folder and add the necessary login credentials, which will grant the VA access without revealing the actual password. Password managers also allow you to revoke access when needed.Encrypted messaging: Share passwords through encrypted messaging platforms like Signal or WhatsApp, which offer end-to-end encryption. This ensures that only the intended recipient can view the message.Temporary or limited access: For platforms that allow it, create temporary or limited access accounts for VAs. This will grant them the necessary access without sharing the main account password. Remember to revoke access when it's no longer needed.Two-factor authentication (2FA): Enable 2FA on accounts to add an extra layer of security. When the VA attempts to log in, you'll receive a verification code that you can provide them to complete the login process.One-time password (OTP) sharing: Use a tool like onetimesecret.com to create a self-destructing message containing the password. Once the recipient reads the message, it will be deleted, leaving no trace of the password.When sharing password access with a VA, it's crucial to maintain trust and security. Make sure to provide access only to necessary accounts and monitor their activity, if possible. Regularly update passwords and revoke access when the VA no longer needs it.

Text: 네, 이제 이 모델 ID를 이용하여 LeftControl 키를 누를 때마다 에너지 볼트를 스폰하는 코드를 작성해 볼게요. 이전에 작성한 코드를 참고하여 아래와 같이 작성해 보세요.luaCopy codefunction OnKeyDown(event)    local key = event.Key    if key == KeyboardKey.LeftControl then        local transform = self.Entity.TransformComponent        local x = transform.Position.x - 1 -- 왼쪽으로 1만큼 이동        local y = transform.Position.y        local z = transform.Position.z        _EffectService:PlayEffect("model://ee0007e4-f128-4cef-8398-5e816359e455", self.Entity, Vector3(x, y, z), 0, Vector3(1, 1, 1), false)    endend_Input.OnKeyDown:Connect(OnKeyDown)이제 LeftControl 키를 누를 때마다, 현재 엔티티 위치의 왼쪽으로 1만큼 이동한 위치에 크기가 1인 번개 에너지 볼트를 스폰합니다. 코드에서 PlayEffect 함수의 첫 번째 인자로 모델 ID를 넘겨줌으로써, 해당 모델 ID를 가진 이펙트를 재생할 수 있습니다.

Text: To create a Docker image with both the backend and frontend, you can use a multi-stage build. This will allow you to build the frontend and backend separately, and then copy the built files into the final container image.Create a Dockerfile in the root directory of your project with the following content:DockerfileCopy code# --- Build frontend ---FROM node:16-alpine as frontend-builderWORKDIR /app/frontendCOPY frontend/package.json frontend/package-lock.json ./RUN npm ciCOPY frontend .RUN npm run build# --- Build backend ---FROM node:16-alpine as backend-builderWORKDIR /app/backendCOPY backend/package.json backend/package-lock.json ./RUN npm ciCOPY backend .RUN npm run build# --- Final container image ---FROM node:16-alpineWORKDIR /appCOPY --from=backend-builder /app/backend /app/backendCOPY --from=frontend-builder /app/frontend/dist /app/frontend/dist# Expose the API portEXPOSE 3000# Set the working directory for the backendWORKDIR /app/backend# Start the backend serverCMD ["npm", "start"]This Dockerfile uses three stages:frontend-builder: Builds the frontend using the Vue CLI. It installs the necessary dependencies, copies the frontend source code, and runs the build command. The built files will be placed in the dist folder.backend-builder: Builds the backend using Node.js. It installs the necessary dependencies and copies the backend source code.The final stage: Copies the built frontend files from the frontend-builder stage and the backend files from the backend-builder stage into a new container image based on the node:16-alpine image. It sets up the working directory and exposes the API port (3000).To build the Docker image, run the following command in the same directory as the Dockerfile:bashCopy codedocker build -t your-image-name .Replace your-image-name with a name for your Docker image.To run the Docker container, use the following command:bashCopy codedocker run -p 3000:3000 your-image-nameThis will start the container and map the API port 3000 to the host machine, allowing you to access the API at http://localhost:3000.

Text: Fukuzawa Yukichi was a 19th century Japanese philosopher and educator who played a major role in the modernization of Japan. In his works, he put forward his ideas about the nature and purpose of civilization, and how it should be approached in the context of Japan's modernization.Fukuzawa believed that civilization was a process of escaping barbarism and advancing towards advanced human comfort and dignity, especially advanced knowledge. He emphasized that what was needed in Japanese society, which was overflowing with virtue, was rather "intelligence." He believed that the progress of civilization had the aspect of the development process of "freedom," and that civilization was the process of expanding freedom to individuals and society away from "the bias of power."The core of civilization, according to Fukuzawa, was the progress of intellect. He emphasized the improvement of the people's intellectual level in his Recommendation of Studies, emphasizing the learning of "real studies" - Western studies.Furthermore, Fukuzawa believed that the purpose of civilization was independence. He argued that the purpose of the country was independence, and that the civilization of the people was a means to achieve this purpose. It is clear that his call for civilization aimed at Western civilization was due to the purpose of "independence."In conclusion, Fukuzawa Yukichi's ideas about civilization were based on the principles of advanced knowledge, the progress of intellect, and independence. He believed that the process of civilization should be driven by the pursuit of intelligence and the expansion of freedom, and that the ultimate goal of civilization was to preserve the independence of the country. These ideas were significant in the modernization of Japan and continue to be relevant in discussions about the purpose of civilization today.

Text: Sure, here's some sample code that generates 10,000 random coordinates and sends them to a geolocation API to get the country information:pythonCopy codeimport randomimport requestsfrom tqdm import tqdm# Set the number of coordinates to generatenum_coordinates = 10000# Create an empty list to store the resultsresults = []# Use tqdm to display progressfor i in tqdm(range(num_coordinates)):    # Generate a random latitude and longitude    lat = random.uniform(-90, 90)    lon = random.uniform(-180, 180)    # Send a request to the geolocation API    try:        response = requests.get(f"https://api.opencagedata.com/geocode/v1/json?q={lat}+{lon}&key=YOUR_API_KEY")        data = response.json()        results.append((lat, lon, data['results'][0]['components']['country']))    except:        results.append((lat, lon, 'NA'))# Create a DataFrame from the resultsimport pandas as pddf_new = pd.DataFrame(results, columns=["latitude", "longitude", "country"])In this code, I am using the OpenCage Geocoding API to get the country information from the coordinates. You need to replace YOUR_API_KEY with your API key to get access to the API. You can sign up for a free API key on the OpenCage website.Also, the requests library is used to send the requests to the API and tqdm library is used to display the progress bar.The script generates random latitude and longitude coordinates using the random.uniform function, and then sends a request to the API to get the country information. The results are stored in a list, and then they are converted into a DataFrame.The try-except block is used to handle any exception that might occur while sending the requests to the API. In case of an exception, the script will append 'NA' to the results list instead of the country name.Please let me know if you have any questions about this code or if there's anything else I can help you with.

Text: Sure, here's a Python script that uses the PIL (Python Imaging Library) to add a border to an image. First, you'll need to install the Pillow library, which is an improved version of the PIL. You can install it using pip:bashCopy codepip install PillowNow, create a Python script called add_border.py and copy the following code into it:pythonCopy codeimport sysfrom PIL import Image, ImageOpsdef add_border(input_image_path, output_image_path, border_size, border_color):    img = Image.open(input_image_path)    img_with_border = ImageOps.expand(img, border=border_size, fill=border_color)    img_with_border.save(output_image_path)if __name__ == "__main__":    if len(sys.argv) != 6:        print("Usage: python add_border.py <input_image> <output_image> <border_size> <border_color>")        sys.exit(1)    input_image_path = sys.argv[1]    output_image_path = sys.argv[2]    border_size = int(sys.argv[3])    border_color = sys.argv[4]    add_border(input_image_path, output_image_path, border_size, border_color)You can now use this script from the command line to add a border to an image:bashCopy codepython add_border.py input_image.png output_image.png 10 "#FFFFFF"This command will add a 10-pixel-wide white border to input_image.png and save the result as output_image.png. You can adjust the border size and color as needed. Make sure to provide the color in hexadecimal format (e.g., #FFFFFF for white).

Text: great.   here is piece (below).   please edit it and maybe add some examples and add some humor too.  thx.  ::  Exploring Generative AI Bias: My Journey with Midjourney  It all started a few weeks ago when my friend Chris Alden sent me a nice note for my birthday– he used Midjourney to send me a: "portrait of Auren Hoffman who is CEO of SafeGraph, graduated from the University of California, Berkeley with a degree in Industrial Engineering in 1996, is a loving husband and father, and a great friend in the style of a Settlers of Catan champion." This is “me” (according to Midjourney)This DOES actually look like me … and I do wear that blue shirt almost every day (though my hair is not nearly as good as this avatar).  Chris and I got into a discussion of whether or not Midjourney could go back in time and so he used this prompt:"portrait of Auren Hoffman who graduated with engineering degree from UC Berkeley"This is actually pretty accurate – I did look a lot like this when I was in college (except for the glasses and the bowtie).  But I get the glasses … that is what the stereotypical engineer wears.  Given that most engineers at UC Berkeley are Asian, we wondered what would happen if we gave it a more generic prompt: "portrait of a graduate with engineering degree from UC Berkeley"Pretty accurate depiction of the average engineer at UC Berkeley (though I’m skeptical that 3 of 4 wear glasses). Missing are women, but Midjourney portraits do seem to track the average engineering student at UC Berkeley …Demographics from UC Berkeley Engineering SchoolAs you can see, the 2019-2020 Engineering student body was about 70% male, and the most heavily represented ethnic group was “Asian” followed by “White” (note that Berkeley groups all the international students together and doesn’t break that group down by ethnicity, so these number are probably a bit off). So I started to get interested to see if AI has a gender bias.  So next I prompted it to draw:“portrait of a pre-med student from UC Berkeley”Again with the glasses! Now, I could not find the gender breakdown stats on pre-med students at UC Berkeley (if anyone has them, please let me know), but I would be surprised if it is less than 50% female. UC Berkeley itself is over 50% women in total and Harvard Medical School is now 56% women.  UCSF is 64.4% women. So,I would be shocked if women were less than 50% of pre-med students at UC Berkeley.  In this case, it does seem that the AI has some sort of bias here. The racial composition is interesting too.  Midjourney seems to think that the average pre-med student at UC Berkeley is East Asian.  The stereotypical pre-med student is South Asian (a stereotype, not necessarily reality, but I would assume that Midjourney might follow the stereotype).  So something is going on here. (Oh yeah, and they all wear glasses)  Given that UC Berkeley is well known for having a very high East Asian population, I wondered if I would get a different representation with a different school as a modifier.  So I tried:“portrait of a pre-med student from Princeton”The bottom two guys do look like a lot of people I know that went to Princeton (they even have that same part in their hair).  But again, no women!  And no South Asians.  And more glasses!Again, Princeton’s ethnic demographics aren’t too far off from the AI’s conception (Princeton is about 40% white and 28% Asian). But like UC Berkeley, Princeton has a nearly 50/50 gender balance.   Maybe pre-med is too hard a major for the AI.  So I tried:"portrait of a graduate with biology degree from UC Berkeley" Here we see all East Asians and finally got our first woman in the second-slot.   I also find it funny that Midjourney decorated two of the portraits with flowers (that is its idea of “biology”).  When I was at Cal, almost everyone that majored in psychology were white women. Cal mirrors the national averages– at least 70% of undergrad psychology degrees are awarded to women.  So let’s try:“portrait of a psychology major from UC Berkeley” What the?  These people don’t exactly scream out psychology (except for maybe the guy with the bow-tie). Again, no women which is really surprising. Women have been receiving the majority of psychology degrees since the mid-1970s, so you would expect the AI to pick up on this.  Maybe the “major” was throwing off the AI.   So let’s try:“portrait of student at UC Berkeley”These aren’t bad.  Pretty much all of them look like Cal students … I mean they even have back-packs.  And we at least got one woman (better than zero).  Now I was getting pretty frustrated, so wanted to try a prompt where one would stereotype women.  So I did:“Portrait of a nursing student at Harvard”Whoa.  We got 4 women!  One of them even has a medal for something and two are already wearing scrubs and stethoscopes.  I’m not sure if Harvard even has a nursing school or not, but at least I did not get a bunch of dudes with ties and glasses.  I wanted to dive in a bit more to see the interesting biases of Midjourney.   My wife studied history at Princeton.  When she was there the major was super diverse (racially and gender) – and I assume it still is (although I couldn’t find any stats on this).  So I tried:“Portrait of history student at Princeton” The upper two portraits seem reasonable.  The upper right one even looks like she’s on the Princeton campus.  The lower left is funny– the dude is posing next to a drawing of … himself!  Is that what history students do?  AI is implying that history students are narcissistic or… something.  The bottom right is even funnier– the student is wearing revolutionary war garb, like it’s a portrait of a young Aaron Burr thinking deeply about his nemesis Hamilton.  So I started to thinking maybe the problem was that I was going for a single person.  I thought maybe it would be more accurate if I asked for plural people.  So let’s try:“Portrait of history students at Princeton”Once we go with the plural “students” we get a lot more women.  Though still not very racially diverse. So we can see through these that the way Midjourney sees these students is definitely much closer to reality in some areas than others. I’m interested to keep exploring where (and why) it’s closest to the truth.  Midjourney as entertainment On a personal note, I freakin’ love playing around with Midjourney.   It is the best $96 I’ve spent in a long time (that was not on donuts).   It’s pushing me to be more creative, and I also love seeing what other people are doing on Midjourney. My biggest takeaway is this:  Creation > consumption There’s so much pull towards “consuming” activities– things like watching a show or a movie, or just scrolling. One of the coolest things about tools like Midjourney is that it lowers the barrier to being a creator.  Creating is way more fun, more fulfilling and more useful than consuming (like watching a movie or TV show).  The iPad and iPhone are all about consuming– passively absorbing content.  The computer is more about creating. Whenever you can, aim to create. And it’s never been easier to create with a computer than it is now.       Thanks to Midjourney and my friend Chris, I now have a few cool portraits of myself as a board game champion and a college student (and some new knowledge of undergraduate student demographics). A whole lot more than I would have gotten out of a Netflix session.  What weird things have you found or made with AI?
Label: h
